key-auth-enc.name: key_names
key-auth-enc.description:
Describes an array of parameter names where the plugin will look for a key. The client must send the
authentication key in one of those key names, and the plugin will try to read the credential from a
header, request body, or query string parameter with the same name.

Key names may only contain [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9], [_] underscore, and [-] hyphen.

key-auth-enc.name: key_in_body
key-auth-enc.description: If enabled, the plugin reads the request body (if said request has one and its MIME type is supported) and tries to find the key in it. Supported MIME types: `application/www-form-urlencoded`, `application/json`, and `multipart/form-data`.

key-auth-enc.name: key_in_header
key-auth-enc.description: If enabled (default), the plugin reads the request header and tries to find the key in it.

key-auth-enc.name: key_in_query
key-auth-enc.description: If enabled (default), the plugin reads the query parameter in the request and tries to find the key in it.

key-auth-enc.name: hide_credentials
key-auth-enc.description:
An optional boolean value telling the plugin to show or hide the credential from the upstream service. If `true`,
the plugin strips the credential from the request (i.e., the header, query string, or request body containing the key) before proxying it.

key-auth-enc.name: anonymous
key-auth-enc.description: An optional string (consumer UUID or username) value to use as an “anonymous” consumer if authentication fails. If empty (default null), the request will fail with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value must refer to the consumer `id` or `username` attribute, and **not** its `custom_id`.

key-auth-enc.name: anonymous
key-auth-enc.description:
An optional string (consumer UUID) value to use as an anonymous consumer if authentication fails.
If empty (default), the request will fail with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value
must refer to the consumer `id` attribute that is internal to Kong Gateway, and **not** its `custom_id`.

key-auth-enc.name: run_on_preflight
key-auth-enc.description:
A boolean value that indicates whether the plugin should run (and try to authenticate) on `OPTIONS` preflight requests.
If set to `false`, then `OPTIONS` requests are always allowed.

key-auth.name: key_names
key-auth.description:
Describes an array of parameter names where the plugin will look for a key. The client must send the authentication key in one of those key names, and the plugin will try to read the credential from a header, request body, or query string parameter with the same name.
**Note**: The key names may only contain [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9], [_] underscore, and [-] hyphen.

key-auth.name: key_in_body
key-auth.description: If enabled, the plugin reads the request body (if said request has one and its MIME type is supported) and tries to find the key in it. Supported MIME types: `application/www-form-urlencoded`, `application/json`, and `multipart/form-data`.

key-auth.name: key_in_header
key-auth.description: If enabled (default), the plugin reads the request header and tries to find the key in it.

key-auth.name: key_in_query
key-auth.description: If enabled (default), the plugin reads the query parameter in the request and tries to find the key in it.

key-auth.name: hide_credentials
key-auth.description:
An optional boolean value telling the plugin to show or hide the credential from the upstream service. If `true`,
the plugin strips the credential from the request (i.e., the header, query string, or request body containing the key) before proxying it.

key-auth.name: anonymous
key-auth.description: An optional string (consumer UUID or username) value to use as an “anonymous” consumer if authentication fails. If empty (default null), the request will fail with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value must refer to the consumer `id` or `username` attribute, and **not** its `custom_id`.

key-auth.name: anonymous
key-auth.description:
An optional string (consumer UUID) value to use as an anonymous consumer if authentication fails.
If empty (default), the request will fail with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value
must refer to the consumer `id` attribute that is internal to Kong Gateway, and **not** its `custom_id`.
For more information, see [Anonymous Access](/gateway/latest/kong-plugins/authentication/reference/#anonymous-access).

key-auth.name: run_on_preflight
key-auth.description:
A boolean value that indicates whether the plugin should run (and try to authenticate) on `OPTIONS` preflight requests.
If set to `false`, then `OPTIONS` requests are always allowed.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: ldap_host
ldap-auth-advanced.description: Host on which the LDAP server is running.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: ldap_port
ldap-auth-advanced.description:
TCP port where the LDAP server is listening. 389 is the default
port for non-SSL LDAP and AD. 636 is the port required for SSL LDAP and AD. If `ldaps` is
configured, you must use port 636.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: ldap_password
ldap-auth-advanced.description: The password to the LDAP server.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: start_tls
ldap-auth-advanced.description:
Set it to `true` to issue StartTLS (Transport Layer Security) extended operation
over `ldap` connection. If the `start_tls` setting is enabled, ensure the `ldaps`
setting is disabled.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: ldaps
ldap-auth-advanced.description:
Set it to `true` to use `ldaps`, a secure protocol (that can be configured
to TLS) to connect to the LDAP server. When `ldaps` is
configured, you must use port 636. If the `ldap` setting is enabled, ensure the
`start_tls` setting is disabled.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: base_dn
ldap-auth-advanced.description: Base DN as the starting point for the search; e.g., "dc=example,dc=com".

ldap-auth-advanced.name: verify_ldap_host
ldap-auth-advanced.description: Set to `true` to authenticate LDAP server. The server certificate will be verified according to the CA certificates specified by the `lua_ssl_trusted_certificate` directive.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: attribute
ldap-auth-advanced.description: Attribute to be used to search the user; e.g., "cn".

ldap-auth-advanced.name: cache_ttl
ldap-auth-advanced.description: Cache expiry time in seconds.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: timeout
ldap-auth-advanced.description: An optional timeout in milliseconds when waiting for connection with LDAP server.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: keepalive
ldap-auth-advanced.description: An optional value in milliseconds that defines how long an idle connection to LDAP server will live before being closed.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: anonymous
ldap-auth-advanced.description: An optional string (consumer UUID or username) value to use as an “anonymous” consumer if authentication fails. If empty (default null), the request will fail with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value must refer to the consumer `id` or `username` attribute, and **not** its `custom_id`.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: anonymous
ldap-auth-advanced.description:
An optional string (consumer UUID) value to use as an anonymous consumer if authentication fails.
If empty (default), the request will fail with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value
must refer to the consumer `id` attribute that is internal to Kong Gateway, and **not** its `custom_id`.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: header_type
ldap-auth-advanced.description:
An optional string to use as part of the Authorization header. By default, a valid Authorization header looks like this:
`Authorization: ldap base64(username:password)`. If `header_type` is set to "basic", then the Authorization header would be
`Authorization: basic base64(username:password)`. Note that `header_type` can take any string, not just `"ldap"` and `"basic"`.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: consumer_optional
ldap-auth-advanced.description:
Whether consumer mapping is optional. If `consumer_optional=true`, the plugin will not attempt to associate a consumer with the
LDAP authenticated user. If `consumer_optional=false`, LDAP authenticated users can still access upstream resources.

To prevent access from LDAP users that are not associated with consumers, set `consumer_optional=false`, set the `anonymous` field to an
existing `consumer_id`, then use the [Request Termination plugin](/hub/kong-inc/request-termination/) to deny any requests from the anonymous consumer.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: consumer_by
ldap-auth-advanced.description: Whether to authenticate consumers based on `username`, `custom_id`, or both.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: hide_credentials
ldap-auth-advanced.description: An optional boolean value telling the plugin to hide the credential to the upstream server. It will be removed by Kong before proxying the request.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: bind_dn
ldap-auth-advanced.description:
The DN to bind to. Used to perform LDAP search of user. This `bind_dn`
should have permissions to search for the user being authenticated.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: group_base_dn
ldap-auth-advanced.description: Sets a distinguished name (DN) for the entry where LDAP searches for groups begin. This field is case-insensitive.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: group_name_attribute
ldap-auth-advanced.description:
Sets the attribute holding the name of a group, typically
called `name` (in Active Directory) or `cn` (in OpenLDAP). This
field is case-insensitive.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: group_member_attribute
ldap-auth-advanced.description: Sets the attribute holding the members of the LDAP group. This field is case-sensitive.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: log_search_results
ldap-auth-advanced.description:
Displays all the LDAP search results received from the LDAP
server for debugging purposes. Not recommended to be enabled in
a production environment.

ldap-auth-advanced.name: groups_required
ldap-auth-advanced.description:
The groups required to be present in the LDAP search result for successful authorization. This config parameter works in both **AND** / **OR** cases.
- When `["group1 group2"]` are in the same array indices, both `group1` AND `group2` need to be present in the LDAP search result.
- When `["group1", "group2"]` are in different array indices, either `group1` OR `group2` need to be present in the LDAP search result.

ldap-auth.name: hide_credentials
ldap-auth.description: An optional boolean value telling the plugin to hide the credential to the upstream server. It will be removed by Kong before proxying the request.

ldap-auth.name: ldap_host
ldap-auth.description: Host on which the LDAP server is running.

ldap-auth.name: ldap_port
ldap-auth.description:
TCP port where the LDAP server is listening. 389 is the default
port for non-SSL LDAP and AD. 636 is the port required for SSL LDAP and AD. If `ldaps` is
configured, you must use port 636.

ldap-auth.name: start_tls
ldap-auth.description:
Set it to `true` to issue StartTLS (Transport Layer Security) extended operation over `ldap`
connection. If the `start_tls` setting is enabled, ensure the `ldaps`
setting is disabled.

ldap-auth.name: ldaps
ldap-auth.description:
Set to `true` to connect using the LDAPS protocol (LDAP over TLS).  When `ldaps` is
configured, you must use port 636. If the `ldap` setting is enabled, ensure the
`start_tls` setting is disabled.

ldap-auth.name: base_dn
ldap-auth.description: Base DN as the starting point for the search; e.g., "dc=example,dc=com".

ldap-auth.name: verify_ldap_host
ldap-auth.description: Set to `true` to authenticate LDAP server. The server certificate will be verified according to the CA certificates specified by the `lua_ssl_trusted_certificate` directive.

ldap-auth.name: attribute
ldap-auth.description: Attribute to be used to search the user; e.g., "cn".

ldap-auth.name: timeout
ldap-auth.description: An optional timeout in milliseconds when waiting for connection with LDAP server.

ldap-auth.name: keepalive
ldap-auth.description: An optional value in milliseconds that defines how long an idle connection to LDAP server will live before being closed.

ldap-auth.name: anonymous
ldap-auth.description: An optional string (consumer UUID or username) value to use as an “anonymous” consumer if authentication fails. If empty (default null), the request fails with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value must refer to the consumer `id` or `username` attribute, and **not** its `custom_id`.

ldap-auth.name: anonymous
ldap-auth.description:
An optional string (consumer UUID) value to use as an anonymous consumer if authentication fails.
If empty (default), the request fails with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value
must refer to the consumer `id` attribute that is internal to Kong Gateway, and **not** its `custom_id`.

ldap-auth.name: header_type
ldap-auth.description: An optional string to use as part of the Authorization header. By default, a valid Authorization header looks like this: `Authorization: ldap base64(username:password)`. If `header_type` is set to "basic", then the Authorization header would be `Authorization: basic base64(username:password)`. Note that `header_type` can take any string, not just `"ldap"` and `"basic"`.

loggly.name: host
loggly.description: The IP address or hostname of Loggly server.

loggly.name: port
loggly.description: The UDP port to send data to on the Loggly server.

loggly.name: tags
loggly.description: An optional list of [tags](https://www.loggly.com/docs/tags/) to support segmentation and filtering of logs.

loggly.name: timeout
loggly.description: An optional timeout in milliseconds when sending data to the Loggly server.

loggly.name: successful_severity
loggly.description:
An optional logging severity assigned to all the successful requests with a response
status code 400. Available options: `debug`, `info`, `notice`, `warning`, `err`,
`crit`, `alert`, `emerg`.

loggly.name: client_errors_severity
loggly.description:
An optional logging severity assigned to all the failed requests with a response
status code 400 or higher but less than 500. Available options: `debug`, `info`,
`notice`, `warning`, `err`, `crit`, `alert`, `emerg`.

loggly.name: server_errors_severity
loggly.description:
An optional logging severity assigned to all the failed requests with response status
code 500 or higher. Available options: `debug`, `info`, `notice`, `warning`, `err`,
`crit`, `alert`, `emerg`.

loggly.name: log_level
loggly.description:
An optional logging severity, any request with equal or higher severity will be
logged to Loggly. Available options: `debug`, `info`, `notice`, `warning`, `err`,
`crit`, `alert`, `emerg`.

loggly.name: custom_fields_by_lua
loggly.description:
A list of key-value pairs, where the key is the name of a log field and
the value is a chunk of Lua code, whose return value sets or replaces
the log field value.

mocking.name: api_specification_filename
mocking.description:
The path and name of the specification file loaded into Kong Gateway's database. You cannot
use this option for DB-less or hybrid mode.

mocking.name: api_specification
mocking.description:
The contents of the specification file. You must use this option for hybrid or DB-less mode.
With this configuration option, you can include the full specification as part of the configuration,
instead of referring to a separate file with `api_specification_filename` that lives next to the Kong Gateway.
In Kong Manager, you can copy and paste the contents of the spec directly into
the `Config.Api Specification` text field.

mocking.name: random_delay
mocking.description:
Enables a random delay in the mocked response. Introduces delays to simulate
real-time response times by APIs.

mocking.name: max_delay_time
mocking.description:
The maximum value in seconds of delay time. Set this value when `random_delay` is enabled
and you want to adjust the default. The value must be greater than the
`min_delay_time`.

mocking.name: min_delay_time
mocking.description:
The minimum value in seconds of delay time. Set this value when `random_delay` is enabled
and you want to adjust the default. The value must be less than the
`max_delay_time`.

mocking.name: random_examples
mocking.description: Randomly selects one example and returns it. This parameter requires the spec to have multiple examples configured.

mocking.name: included_status_codes
mocking.description: A global list of the HTTP status codes that can only be selected and returned.

mocking.name: random_status_code
mocking.description:
Determines whether to randomly select an HTTP status code from the responses of the corresponding API method.
The default value is `false`, which means the minimum HTTP status code is always selected and returned.

mtls-auth.name: anonymous
mtls-auth.description: An optional string (consumer UUID or username) value to use as an “anonymous” consumer if authentication fails. If empty (default null), the request fails with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value must refer to the consumer `id` or `username` attribute, and **not** its `custom_id`.

mtls-auth.name: anonymous
mtls-auth.description:
An optional string (consumer UUID) value to use as an "anonymous" consumer if authentication fails.
If the request is left empty (which it is by default), it fails with an authentication failure of either
`HTTP 495` if the client presented a certificate that is not acceptable, or `HTTP 496` if the client failed
to present certificate as requested. Please note that this value must refer to the consumer `id`
attribute, which is internal to Kong, and **not** its `custom_id`.

mtls-auth.name: consumer_by
mtls-auth.description: Whether to match the subject name of the client-supplied certificate against consumer's `username` and/or `custom_id` attribute. If set to `[]` (the empty array), then auto-matching is disabled.

mtls-auth.name: ca_certificates
mtls-auth.description:
List of CA Certificates strings to use as Certificate Authorities (CA) when validating a client certificate.
At least one is required but you can specify as many as needed. The value of this array is comprised
of primary keys (`id`).

mtls-auth.name: skip_consumer_lookup
mtls-auth.description: Skip consumer lookup once certificate is trusted against the configured CA list.

mtls-auth.name: authenticated_group_by
mtls-auth.description:
Certificate property to use as the authenticated group. Valid values are `CN` (Common Name) or
`DN` (Distinguished Name). Once `skip_consumer_lookup` is applied, any client with a
valid certificate can access the Service/API. To restrict usage to only some of the authenticated users,
also add the ACL plugin (not covered here) and create allowed or denied groups of users.

mtls-auth.name: revocation_check_mode
mtls-auth.description:
>**Known Issue:** The default value `IGNORE_CA_ERROR` has a known issue in versions 1.5.0.0 and later.
As a workaround, manually set the value to `SKIP`.

Controls client certificate revocation check behavior. Valid values are `SKIP`, `IGNORE_CA_ERROR`, or `STRICT`.
If set to `SKIP`, no revocation check is performed. If set to `IGNORE_CA_ERROR`, the plugin respects
the revocation status when either OCSP or CRL URL is set, and doesn't fail on network issues. If set to `STRICT`,
the plugin only treats the certificate as valid when it's able to verify the revocation status, and a missing
OCSP or CRL URL in the certificate or a failure to connect to the server results in a revoked status.
If both OCSP and CRL URL are set, the plugin always checks OCSP first, and only checks the CRL URL if
it can't communicate with the OCSP server.

mtls-auth.name: http_timeout
mtls-auth.description: HTTP timeout threshold in milliseconds when communicating with the OCSP server or downloading CRL.

mtls-auth.name: cert_cache_ttl
mtls-auth.description: The length of time in milliseconds between refreshes of the revocation check status cache.

mtls-auth.name: http_proxy_host
mtls-auth.description:
The HTTP hostname or IP address of a proxy. Use this setting with
`http_proxy_port` to access a certificate revocation list
(CRL) or an OCSP server.

Required if `http_proxy_port` is set.

mtls-auth.name: http_proxy_port
mtls-auth.description:
The TCP port of the HTTP proxy.

Required if `http_proxy_host` is set.

mtls-auth.name: https_proxy_host
mtls-auth.description:
The HTTPS hostname or IP address of a proxy. Use this setting with
`https_proxy_port` to access a certificate revocation list
(CRL) or an OCSP server.

Required if `https_proxy_port` is set.

mtls-auth.name: https_proxy_port
mtls-auth.description:
The TCP port of the HTTPS proxy.

Required if `https_proxy_host` is set.

mtls-auth.name: send_ca_dn
mtls-auth.description: Sends the distinguished names (DN) of the configured CA list in the TLS handshake message.

mtls-auth.name: allow_partial_chain
mtls-auth.description:
Allow certificate verification with only an intermediate certificate.
When this is enabled, you don't need to upload the full chain to Kong Certificates.

oas-validation.name: api_spec
oas-validation.description: The API specification defined using either Swagger or the OpenAPI. This can be either a JSON or YAML based file. If using a YAML file, the spec needs to be URL encoded to preserve the YAML format.

oas-validation.name: validate_request_uri_params
oas-validation.description: If set to true, validates URI parameters in the request against the API specification.

oas-validation.name: validate_request_header_params
oas-validation.description: If set to true, validates HTTP header parameters against the API specification.

oas-validation.name: validate_request_query_params
oas-validation.description: If set to true, validates query parameters against the API specification.

oas-validation.name: validate_request_body
oas-validation.description: If set to true, validates the request body content against the API specification.

oas-validation.name: notify_only_request_validation_failure
oas-validation.description: If set to true, notifications via event hooks are enabled, but request based validation failures don't affect the request flow.

oas-validation.name: validate_response_body
oas-validation.description: If set to true, validates the response from the upstream services against the API specification. If validation fails, it results in an `HTTP 406 Not Acceptable` status code.

oas-validation.name: notify_only_response_body_validation_failure
oas-validation.description: If set to true, notifications via event hooks are enabled, but response validation failures don't affect the response flow.

oas-validation.name: header_parameter_check
oas-validation.description: If set to true, checks if HTTP header parameters in the request exist in the API specification.

oas-validation.name: query_parameter_check
oas-validation.description: If set to true, checks if query parameters in the request exist in the API specification.

oas-validation.name: allowed_header_parameters
oas-validation.description:
List of header parameters in the request that will be ignored when performing HTTP header validation. These are additional headers added to an API request beyond those defined in the API specification.

For example, you might include the HTTP header `User-Agent`, which lets servers and network peers identify the application, operating system, vendor, and/or version of the requesting user agent.

oas-validation.name: verbose_response
oas-validation.description: If set to true, returns a detailed error message for invalid requests & responses. This is useful while testing.

oauth2-introspection.name: introspection_url
oauth2-introspection.description:
The full URL to the third-party introspection endpoint.

If the introspection endpoint is `https`, [`lua_ssl_trusted_certificate`](/gateway/latest/reference/configuration/#lua_ssl_trusted_certificate)
must be set in `kong.conf` to ensure the plugin can connect
to the endpoint. The CA bundle file location depends on your OS. See the
[configuration reference](/gateway/latest/reference/configuration/#lua_ssl_trusted_certificate) for a list.

Starting with Kong v2.2, users can set `lua_ssl_trusted_certificate=system`
to automatically use the CA bundle from the OS.

oauth2-introspection.name: authorization_value
oauth2-introspection.description: The value to set as the `Authorization` header when querying the introspection endpoint. This depends on the OAuth 2.0 server, but usually is the `client_id` and `client_secret` as a Base64-encoded Basic Auth string (`Basic MG9hNWl...`).

oauth2-introspection.name: token_type_hint
oauth2-introspection.description: The `token_type_hint` value to associate to introspection requests.

oauth2-introspection.name: ttl
oauth2-introspection.description: The TTL in seconds for the introspection response. Set to 0 to disable the expiration.

oauth2-introspection.name: hide_credentials
oauth2-introspection.description: An optional boolean value telling the plugin to hide the credential to the upstream API server. It will be removed by Kong before proxying the request.

oauth2-introspection.name: timeout
oauth2-introspection.description: An optional timeout in milliseconds when sending data to the upstream server.

oauth2-introspection.name: keepalive
oauth2-introspection.description: An optional value in milliseconds that defines how long an idle connection lives before being closed.

oauth2-introspection.name: anonymous
oauth2-introspection.description: An optional string (consumer UUID or username) value to use as an “anonymous” consumer if authentication fails. If empty (default null), the request fails with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value must refer to the consumer `id` or `username` attribute, and **not** its `custom_id`.

oauth2-introspection.name: anonymous
oauth2-introspection.description: An optional string (consumer UUID) value to use as an anonymous consumer if authentication fails. If empty (default), the request fails with an authentication failure `4xx`.

oauth2-introspection.name: run_on_preflight
oauth2-introspection.description: A boolean value that indicates whether the plugin should run (and try to authenticate) on `OPTIONS` preflight requests. If set to `false`, then `OPTIONS` requests will always be allowed.

oauth2-introspection.name: consumer_by
oauth2-introspection.description:
A string indicating whether to associate OAuth2 `username` or `client_id`
with the consumer's username. OAuth2 `username` is mapped to a consumer's
`username` field, while an OAuth2 `client_id` maps to a consumer's
`custom_id`.

oauth2-introspection.name: introspect_request
oauth2-introspection.description:
A boolean indicating whether to forward information about the current
downstream request to the introspect endpoint. If true, headers
`X-Request-Path` and `X-Request-Http-Method` will be inserted into the
introspect request.

oauth2-introspection.name: custom_introspection_headers
oauth2-introspection.datatype: map of string keys and string values
oauth2-introspection.description: A list of custom headers to be added in the introspection request.

oauth2-introspection.name: custom_claims_forward
oauth2-introspection.description:
A list of custom claims to be forwarded from the introspection response
to the upstream request. Claims are forwarded in headers with prefix
`X-Credential-{claim-name}`.

oauth2.name: scopes
oauth2.description:
Describes an array of scope names that will be available to the end user. If `mandatory_scope` is
set to `true`, then `scopes` are required.

oauth2.name: mandatory_scope
oauth2.description: An optional boolean value telling the plugin to require at least one `scope` to be authorized by the end user.

oauth2.name: provision_key
oauth2.description: The unique key the plugin has generated when it has been added to the Service.

oauth2.name: token_expiration
oauth2.description:
An optional integer value telling the plugin how many seconds a token should last, after which the client will
need to refresh the token. Set to `0` to disable the expiration.

oauth2.name: enable_authorization_code
oauth2.description: An optional boolean value to enable the three-legged Authorization Code flow ([RFC 6742 Section 4.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.1)).

oauth2.name: enable_client_credentials
oauth2.description: An optional boolean value to enable the Client Credentials Grant flow ([RFC 6742 Section 4.4](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.4)).

oauth2.name: enable_implicit_grant
oauth2.description: An optional boolean value to enable the Implicit Grant flow which allows to provision a token as a result of the authorization process ([RFC 6742 Section 4.2](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.2)).

oauth2.name: enable_password_grant
oauth2.description: An optional boolean value to enable the Resource Owner Password Credentials Grant flow ([RFC 6742 Section 4.3](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.3)).

oauth2.name: auth_header_name
oauth2.description: The name of the header that is supposed to carry the access token. Default: `authorization`.

oauth2.name: hide_credentials
oauth2.description:
An optional boolean value telling the plugin to show or hide the credential from the upstream service.
If `true`, the plugin will strip the credential from the request (the header containing the client credentials)
before proxying it.

oauth2.name: accept_http_if_already_terminated
oauth2.description:
Accepts HTTPs requests that have already been terminated by a proxy or load balancer and the
`x-forwarded-proto: https` header has been added to the request. Only enable this option
if the Kong server cannot be publicly accessed and the only entry point is such proxy or load balancer.

oauth2.name: anonymous
oauth2.description: An optional string (consumer UUID or username) value to use as an “anonymous” consumer if authentication fails. If empty (default null), the request fails with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value must refer to the consumer `id` or `username` attribute, and **not** its `custom_id`.

oauth2.name: anonymous
oauth2.description:
An optional string (consumer UUID) value to use as an anonymous consumer if authentication fails.
If empty (default), the request fails with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value
must refer to the consumer `id` attribute that is internal to Kong Gateway, and **not** its `custom_id`.

oauth2.name: global_credentials
oauth2.description:
An optional boolean value that allows using the same OAuth credentials generated by the plugin with
any other Service whose OAuth 2.0 plugin configuration also has `config.global_credentials=true`.

oauth2.name: refresh_token_ttl
oauth2.description:
An optional integer value telling the plugin how many seconds a token/refresh token pair is valid for,
and can be used to generate a new access token. Default value is 2 weeks. Set to `0` to keep the token/refresh
token pair valid indefinitely.

oauth2.name: reuse_refresh_token
oauth2.description:
An optional boolean value that indicates whether an OAuth refresh token is
reused when refreshing an access token.

oauth2.name: pkce
oauth2.description:
Specifies a mode of how the Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE) should be
handled by the plugin. The possible modes are `none`, `lax`, and `strict`.
The `strict` mode enforces PKCE on both authorization and token endpoints for
all the clients. The `lax` mode enforces PKCE for public clients, but it does
not enforce it for confidential clients. The `none` mode does not enforce PKCE
on any client. In any case, if a client asks for PKCE on authorization
endpoint, the PKCE is also enforced on token endpoint.

opa.name: opa_protocol
opa.description: The protocol to use when talking to Open Policy Agent (OPA) server. Allowed protocols are `http` and `https`.

opa.name: opa_host
opa.description: The DNS name or IP address of the OPA server.

opa.name: opa_port
opa.description: The port of the OPA server.

opa.name: opa_path
opa.description:
The HTTP path to use when making a request to the OPA server. This is usually the path to the policy and rule to evaluate, prefixed with `/v1/data/`. For example,
if you want to evaluate the `allow` rule inside `example.kong` package, then the path would be `/v1/data/example/kong/allowBoolean`.

opa.name: include_service_in_opa_input
opa.description: If set to true, the Kong Gateway Service object in use for the current request is included as input to OPA.

opa.name: include_route_in_opa_input
opa.description: If set to true, the Kong Gateway Route object in use for the current request is included as input to OPA.

opa.name: include_consumer_in_opa_input
opa.description: If set to true, the Kong Gateway Consumer object in use for the current request (if any) is included as input to OPA.

opa.name: include_body_in_opa_input
opa.description: If set to true, the current requests' request body is included as input to OPA.

opa.name: include_parsed_json_body_in_opa_input
opa.description: If set to true and the `Content-Type` header of the current request is `application/json`, the request body will be JSON decoded and the decoded struct is included as input to OPA.

opa.name: include_uri_captures_in_opa_input
opa.description: If set to true, the [regex capture groups](https://docs.konghq.com/gateway/latest/reference/proxy/#using-regex-in-paths) captured on the Kong Gateway Route's path field in the current request (if any) are included as input to OPA.

opa.name: ssl_verify
opa.description: If set to true, the OPA certificate will be verified according to the CA certificates specified in [lua_ssl_trusted_certificate](/gateway/latest/reference/configuration/#lua_ssl_trusted_certificate).

openid-connect.description: Parameters for enabling only grants/credentials that you want to use.

openid-connect.name: auth_methods
openid-connect.description:
Types of credentials/grants to enable:
- `password`: OAuth legacy password grant
- `client_credentials`: OAuth client credentials grant
- `authorization_code`: authorization code flow
- `bearer`: JWT access token verification
- `introspection`: OAuth introspection
- `userinfo`: OpenID Connect user info endpoint authentication
- `kong_oauth2`: Kong OAuth plugin issued tokens verification
- `refresh_token`: OAuth refresh token grant
- `session`: session cookie authentication
Parameter for allowing anonymous access. This parameter is disabled by default.

openid-connect.name: anonymous
openid-connect.description: An optional string (consumer UUID or username) value that functions as an “anonymous” consumer if authentication fails. If empty (default null), requests that fail authentication will return a `4xx` HTTP status code. This value must refer to the consumer `id` or `username` attribute, and **not** its `custom_id`.

openid-connect.name: anonymous
openid-connect.description:
An optional string (consumer UUID) value to use as an anonymous consumer if authentication fails.
If empty (default), the request will fail with an authentication failure `4xx`. Note that this value
must refer to the consumer `id` attribute that is internal to Kong Gateway, and **not** its `custom_id`.
Parameters for settings that affect different grants and flows.

openid-connect.name: preserve_query_args
openid-connect.description:
With this parameter, you can preserve request query arguments even when doing authorization code flow.
> When this parameter is used with the `config.login_action=redirect` parameter, the browser location
> will change and display the original query arguments. Otherwise, the upstream request
> is modified to include the original query arguments, and the browser will not display
> them in the location field.

openid-connect.name: refresh_tokens
openid-connect.description:
Specifies whether the plugin should try to refresh (soon to be) expired access tokens if the
plugin has a `refresh_token` available.

openid-connect.name: hide_credentials
openid-connect.description:
Remove the credentials used for authentication from the request.
> If multiple credentials are sent with the same request, the plugin will
> remove those that were used for successful authentication.

openid-connect.name: search_user_info
openid-connect.description:
Specify whether to use the user info endpoint to get additional claims for consumer mapping,
credential mapping, authenticated groups, and upstream and downstream headers.
> This requires an extra round-trip and can add latency, but the plugin can also cache
> user info requests (see: `config.cache_user_info`).
Parameters for auto-configuring most of the settings and providing the means for key rotation.

openid-connect.name: issuer
openid-connect.description:
The discovery endpoint (or the issuer identifier).
> When using Kong with the database, the discovery information and the JWKS
> are cached to the Kong configuration database.

openid-connect.name: rediscovery_lifetime
openid-connect.description:
Specifies how long (in seconds) the plugin waits between discovery attempts. Discovery is still triggered on an as-needed basis.
> The re-discovery usually happens when the plugin cannot find a key for verifying
> the signature. For example, if a token is presented for which Kong does not have a
> JWK cached, it will poll the discovery endpoint for new JWK data. If that discovery
> attempt does not yield a JWK that can validate the token, Kong will wait the specified
> number of seconds before retrying the discovery.

openid-connect.name: client_id
openid-connect.datatype: array of string elements (the plugin supports multiple clients)
openid-connect.description:
The client id(s) that the plugin uses when it calls authenticated endpoints on the identity provider.
Other settings that are associated with the client are:
- `config.client_secret`
- `config.client_auth`
- `config.client_jwk`
- `config.client_alg`
- `config.redirect_uri`
- `config.login_redirect_uri`
- `config.logout_redirect_uri`
- `config.unauthorized_redirect_uri`
- `config.forbidden_redirect_uri`
- `config.unexpected_redirect_uri`

Use the same array index when configuring related settings for the client.

openid-connect.name: client_arg
openid-connect.description:
The client to use for this request (the selection is made with a request parameter with the same name).
For example, setting this value to `Client`, and sending the request header `Client: 1` will cause the plugin
to use the first client (see: `config.client_id`) from the client array.
Parameters for configuring how the client should authenticate with the identity provider.

openid-connect.name: client_auth
openid-connect.datatype: array of string elements (one for each client)
openid-connect.description:
The authentication method used by the client (plugin) when calling the endpoints:
- `client_secret_basic`: send `client_id` and `client_secret` in `Authorization: Basic` header
- `client_secret_post`: send `client_id` and `client_secret` as part of the body
- `client_secret_jwt`: send client assertion signed with the `client_secret` as part of the body
- `private_key_jwt`:  send client assertion signed with the `private key` as part of the body
- `none`: do not authenticate


> Private keys can be stored in a database, and they are by the default automatically generated
> in the database. It is also possible to specify private keys with `config.client_jwk` directly
> in the plugin configuration.

openid-connect.name: client_secret
openid-connect.datatype: array of string elements (one for each client)
openid-connect.description:
The client secret.
> Specify one if using `client_secret_*` authentication with the client on
> the identity provider endpoints.

openid-connect.name: client_jwk
openid-connect.datatype: array of JWK records (one for each client)
openid-connect.description: The JWK used for the `private_key_jwt` authentication.

openid-connect.name: client_alg
openid-connect.datatype: array of string elements (one for each client)
openid-connect.description:
The algorithm to use for `client_secret_jwt` (only `HS***`) or `private_key_jwt` authentication:
- `HS256`: HMAC using SHA-256
- `HS384`: HMAC using SHA-384
- `HS512`: HMAC using SHA-512
- `RS256`: RSASSA-PKCS1-v1_5 using SHA-256
- `RS512`: RSASSA-PKCS1-v1_5 using SHA-512
- `ES256`: ECDSA using P-256 and SHA-256
- `ES384`: ECDSA using P-384 and SHA-384
- `ES512`: ECDSA using P-521 and SHA-512
- `PS256`: RSASSA-PSS using SHA-256 and MGF1 with SHA-256
- `PS384`: RSASSA-PSS using SHA-384 and MGF1 with SHA-384
- `PS512`: RSASSA-PSS using SHA-512 and MGF1 with SHA-512
- `EdDSA`: EdDSA with Ed25519
Parameters for specifying the location of the bearer token, and introspection options.

openid-connect.name: bearer_token_param_type
openid-connect.description:
Where to look for the bearer token:
- `header`: search the HTTP headers
- `query`: search the URL's query string
- `body`: search the HTTP request body
- `cookie`: search the HTTP request cookies specified with `config.bearer_token_cookie_name`

openid-connect.name: bearer_token_cookie_name
openid-connect.description: The name of the cookie in which the bearer token is passed.

openid-connect.name: introspect_jwt_tokens
openid-connect.description: Specifies whether to introspect the JWT access tokens (can be used to check for revocations).
Parameters specifying the location of client credentials.

openid-connect.name: client_credentials_param_type
openid-connect.description:
Where to look for the client credentials:
- `header`: search the HTTP headers
- `query`: search the URL's query string
- `body`: search from the HTTP request body
Parameters for where to look for the username and password.

openid-connect.name: password_param_type
openid-connect.description:
Where to look for the username and password:
- `header`: search the HTTP headers
- `query`: search the URL's query string
- `body`: search the HTTP request body
Parameters for where to look for the refresh token (rarely used as the refresh tokens are in many cases bound to the client).

openid-connect.name: refresh_token_param_type
openid-connect.description:
Where to look for the refresh token:
- `header`: search the HTTP headers
- `query`: search the URL's query string
- `body`: search the HTTP request body

openid-connect.name: refresh_token_param_name
openid-connect.description: The name of the parameter used to pass the refresh token.
Parameters for where to look for the id token (rarely sent as part of the request).

openid-connect.name: id_token_param_type
openid-connect.description:
Where to look for the id token:
- `header`: search the HTTP headers
- `query`: search the URL's query string
- `body`: search the HTTP request body

openid-connect.name: id_token_param_name
openid-connect.description: The name of the parameter used to pass the id token.
Parameters for mapping external identity provider managed identities to Kong managed ones.

openid-connect.name: admin_claim
openid-connect.description: The claim used for admin mapping for Kong Manager. Required if mapping IdP claims to Kong Manager admins.

openid-connect.name: consumer_claim
openid-connect.description: The claim used for consumer mapping.

openid-connect.name: consumer_by
openid-connect.description:
Consumer fields used for mapping:
- `id`: try to find the matching Consumer by `id`
- `username`: try to find the matching Consumer by `username`
- `custom_id`: try to find the matching Consumer by `custom_id`

openid-connect.name: by_username_ignore_case
openid-connect.description: If `consumer_by` is set to `username`, specify whether `username` can match consumers case-insensitively.

openid-connect.name: consumer_optional
openid-connect.description: Do not terminate the request if consumer mapping fails.
Parameters for mapping external identity provider managed identities to a Kong credential (virtual in this case).

openid-connect.name: credential_claim
openid-connect.description: The claim used to derive virtual credentials (e.g. to be consumed by the rate-limiting plugin), in case the consumer mapping is not used.

openid-connect.name: issuers_allowed
openid-connect.description: The issuers allowed to be present in the tokens (`iss` claim).

openid-connect.name: authenticated_groups_claim
openid-connect.description:
The claim that contains authenticated groups. This setting can be used together
with ACL plugin, but it also enables IdP managed groups with other applications
and integrations (for example, Kong Manager and Dev Portal). The OpenID Connect
plugin itself does not do anything other than set the context value.

openid-connect.name: scopes_required
openid-connect.description:
The scopes (`scopes_claim` claim) required to be present in the access token (or introspection results) for successful authorization. This config parameter works in both **AND** / **OR** cases.
- When `["scope1 scope2"]` are in the same array indices, both `scope1` AND `scope2` need to be present in access token (or introspection results).
- When `["scope1", "scope2"]` are in different array indices, either `scope1` OR `scope2` need to be present in access token (or introspection results).

openid-connect.name: scopes_claim
openid-connect.description: The claim that contains the scopes.

openid-connect.name: audience_required
openid-connect.description:
The audiences (`audience_claim` claim) required to be present in the access token (or introspection results) for successful authorization. This config parameter works in both **AND** / **OR** cases.
- When `["audience1 audience2"]` are in the same array indices, both `audience1` AND `audience2` need to be present in access token (or introspection results).
- When `["audience1", "audience2"]` are in different array indices, either `audience1` OR `audience2` need to be present in access token (or introspection results).

openid-connect.name: audience_claim
openid-connect.description: The claim that contains the audience.

openid-connect.name: groups_required
openid-connect.description:
The groups (`groups_claim` claim) required to be present in the access token (or introspection results) for successful authorization. This config parameter works in both **AND** / **OR** cases.
- When `["group1 group2"]` are in the same array indices, both `group1` AND `group2` need to be present in access token (or introspection results).
- When `["group1", "group2"]` are in different array indices, either `group1` OR `group2` need to be present in access token (or introspection results).

openid-connect.name: groups_claim
openid-connect.description: The claim that contains the groups.

openid-connect.name: roles_required
openid-connect.description:
The roles (`roles_claim` claim) required to be present in the access token (or introspection results) for successful authorization. This config parameter works in both **AND** / **OR** cases.
- When `["role1 role2"]` are in the same array indices, both `role1` AND `role2` need to be present in access token (or introspection results).
- When `["role1", "role2"]` are in different array indices, either `role1` OR `role2` need to be present in access token (or introspection results).

openid-connect.name: roles_claim
openid-connect.description: The claim that contains the roles.
Parameters for verification rules for standard claims.

openid-connect.name: verify_claims
openid-connect.description: Verify tokens for standard claims.

openid-connect.name: leeway
openid-connect.description: Allow some leeway on the ttl / expiry verification.

openid-connect.name: domains
openid-connect.description: The allowed values for the `hd` claim.

openid-connect.name: max_age
openid-connect.description: The maximum age (in seconds) compared to the `auth_time` claim.

openid-connect.name: jwt_session_claim
openid-connect.description: The claim to match against the JWT session cookie.

openid-connect.name: jwt_session_cookie
openid-connect.description: The name of the JWT session cookie.

openid-connect.name: verify_signature
openid-connect.description: Verify signature of tokens.

openid-connect.name: enable_hs_signatures
openid-connect.description: Enable shared secret, for example, HS256, signatures (when disabled they will not be accepted).

openid-connect.name: ignore_signature
openid-connect.description:
Skip the token signature verification on certain grants:
- `password`: OAuth password grant
- `client_credentials`: OAuth client credentials grant
- `authorization_code`: authorization code flow
- `refresh_token`: OAuth refresh token grant
- `session`: session cookie authentication
- `introspection`: OAuth introspection
- `userinfo`: OpenID Connect user info endpoint authentication

openid-connect.name: extra_jwks_uris
openid-connect.description: JWKS URIs whose public keys are trusted (in addition to the keys found with the discovery).

openid-connect.name: verify_nonce
openid-connect.description: Verify nonce on authorization code flow.

openid-connect.name: introspection_check_active
openid-connect.description: Check that the introspection response has an `active` claim with a value of `true`.

openid-connect.name: verify_parameters
openid-connect.description: Verify plugin configuration against discovery.

openid-connect.description: The downstream user info JWT header (in case the user info returns a JWT response).

openid-connect.description: The downstream session id header.

openid-connect.name: run_on_preflight
openid-connect.description: Specifies whether to run this plugin on pre-flight (`OPTIONS`) requests.
Parameters for what action the plugin completes after a successful login.

openid-connect.name: login_methods
openid-connect.description:
Enable login functionality with specified grants:
- `password`: enable for OAuth password grant
- `client_credentials`: enable OAuth client credentials grant
- `authorization_code`: enable for authorization code flow
- `bearer`: enable for JWT access token authentication
- `introspection`: enable for OAuth introspection authentication
- `userinfo`: enable for OpenID Connect user info endpoint authentication
- `kong_oauth2`: enable for Kong OAuth Plugin authentication
- `refresh_token`: enable for OAuth refresh token grant
- `session`: enable for session cookie authentication

openid-connect.name: login_action
openid-connect.description:
What to do after successful login:
- `upstream`: proxy request to upstream service
- `response`: terminate request with a response
- `redirect`: redirect to a different location

openid-connect.name: login_tokens
openid-connect.description:
What tokens to include in `response` body or `redirect` query string or fragment:
- `id_token`: include id token
- `access_token`: include access token
- `refresh_token`: include refresh token
- `tokens`: include the full token endpoint response
- `introspection`: include introspection response

openid-connect.name: login_redirect_mode
openid-connect.description:
Where to place `login_tokens` when using `redirect` `login_action`:
- `query`: place tokens in query string
- `fragment`: place tokens in url fragment (not readable by servers)

openid-connect.name: login_redirect_uri
openid-connect.datatype: array of urls (one for each client)
openid-connect.description:
Where to redirect the client when `login_action` is set to `redirect`.
> Tip: Leave this empty and the plugin will redirect the client to the URL that originally initiated the
> flow with possible query args preserved from the original request when `config.preserve_query_args`
> is enabled.
Parameters for triggering logout with the plugin and the actions to take on logout.

openid-connect.name: logout_query_arg
openid-connect.description: The request query argument that activates the logout.

openid-connect.name: logout_post_arg
openid-connect.description: The request body argument that activates the logout.

openid-connect.name: logout_uri_suffix
openid-connect.description: The request URI suffix that activates the logout.

openid-connect.name: logout_methods
openid-connect.description:
The request methods that can activate the logout:
- `POST`: HTTP POST method
- `GET`: HTTP GET method
- `DELETE`: HTTP DELETE method

openid-connect.name: logout_revoke
openid-connect.description: Revoke tokens as part of the logout.

openid-connect.name: logout_revoke_access_token
openid-connect.description: Revoke the access token as part of the logout.

openid-connect.name: logout_revoke_refresh_token
openid-connect.description: Revoke the refresh token as part of the logout.

openid-connect.name: logout_redirect_uri
openid-connect.datatype: array of urls (one for each client)
openid-connect.description: Where to redirect the client after the logout.

openid-connect.name: unauthorized_redirect_uri
openid-connect.datatype: array of urls (one for each client)
openid-connect.description: Where to redirect the client on unauthorized requests.

openid-connect.name: unauthorized_error_message
openid-connect.description: The error message for the unauthorized requests (when not using the redirection).
Parameters for how to handle forbidden requests.

openid-connect.name: forbidden_redirect_uri
openid-connect.datatype: array of urls (one for each client)
openid-connect.description: Where to redirect the client on forbidden requests.

openid-connect.name: forbidden_error_message
openid-connect.description: The error message for the forbidden requests (when not using the redirection).

openid-connect.name: forbidden_destroy_session
openid-connect.description: Destroy any active session for the forbidden requests.
Parameters for how to handle unexpected errors.

openid-connect.name: unexpected_redirect_uri
openid-connect.datatype: array of urls (one for each client)
openid-connect.description: Where to redirect the client when unexpected errors happen with the requests.

openid-connect.name: display_errors
openid-connect.description: Display errors on failure responses.
Parameters used during authorization code flow for verification and preserving settings.

openid-connect.name: authorization_cookie_name
openid-connect.description: The authorization cookie name.

openid-connect.name: authorization_cookie_lifetime
openid-connect.description: The authorization cookie lifetime in seconds.

openid-connect.name: authorization_rolling_timeout
openid-connect.description:
The authorization cookie rolling timeout in seconds.
Specifies how long the authorization cookie can be used until it needs to be renewed.

openid-connect.name: authorization_cookie_path
openid-connect.description: The authorization cookie Path flag.

openid-connect.name: authorization_cookie_domain
openid-connect.description: The authorization cookie Domain flag.

openid-connect.name: authorization_cookie_samesite
openid-connect.description:
Controls whether a cookie is sent with cross-origin requests, providing some protection against cross-site request forgery attacks:
- `Strict`: Cookies will only be sent in a first-party context and not be sent along with requests initiated by third party websites.
- `Lax`: Cookies are not sent on normal cross-site subrequests (for example to load images or frames into a third party site), but are sent when a user is navigating to the origin site (for instance, when following a link).
- `None`: Cookies will be sent in all contexts, for example in responses to both first-party and cross-origin requests. If `SameSite=None` is set, the cookie Secure attribute must also be set (or the cookie will be blocked).
- `off`: Do not set the SameSite flag.

openid-connect.name: authorization_cookie_same_site
openid-connect.description:
Controls whether a cookie is sent with cross-origin requests, providing some protection against cross-site request forgery attacks:
- `Strict`: Cookies will only be sent in a first-party context and not be sent along with requests initiated by third party websites.
- `Lax`: Cookies are not sent on normal cross-site subrequests (for example to load images or frames into a third party site), but are sent when a user is navigating to the origin site (for instance, when following a link).
- `None`: Cookies will be sent in all contexts, for example in responses to both first-party and cross-origin requests. If `SameSite=None` is set, the cookie Secure attribute must also be set (or the cookie will be blocked).
- `Default`: Do not explicitly specify a SameSite attribute.

openid-connect.name: authorization_cookie_httponly
openid-connect.description: Forbids JavaScript from accessing the cookie, for example, through the `Document.cookie` property.

openid-connect.name: authorization_cookie_http_only
openid-connect.description: Forbids JavaScript from accessing the cookie, for example, through the `Document.cookie` property.

openid-connect.name: authorization_cookie_secure
openid-connect.description:
Cookie is only sent to the server when a request is made with the https: scheme (except on localhost),
and therefore is more resistant to man-in-the-middle attacks.

Controls whether a cookie is sent with cross-origin requests, providing some protection against cross-site request forgery attacks:
- `Strict`: Cookies will only be sent in a first-party context and not be sent along with requests initiated by third party websites.
- `Lax`: Cookies are not sent on normal cross-site subrequests (for example to load images or frames into a third party site), but are sent when a user is navigating to the origin site (for example, when following a link).

- `off`: Do not set the SameSite flag.

openid-connect.name: session_cookie_same_site
openid-connect.description:
Controls whether a cookie is sent with cross-origin requests, providing some protection against cross-site request forgery attacks:
- `Strict`: Cookies will only be sent in a first-party context and aren't sent along with requests initiated by third party websites.
- `Lax`: Cookies are not sent on normal cross-site subrequests (for example to load images or frames into a third party site), but are sent when a user is navigating to the origin site (for example, when following a link).
- `None`: Cookies will be sent in all contexts, for example in responses to both first party and cross-origin requests. If `SameSite=None` is set, the cookie `Secure` attribute must also be set, or the cookie will be blocked.
- `Default`: Do not explicitly specify a `SameSite` attribute.

openid-connect.name: session_cookie_httponly
openid-connect.description: Forbids JavaScript from accessing the cookie, for example, through the `Document.cookie` property.

openid-connect.name: session_cookie_http_only
openid-connect.description: Forbids JavaScript from accessing the cookie, for example, through the `Document.cookie` property.

openid-connect.name: session_cookie_secure
openid-connect.description:
Cookie is only sent to the server when a request is made with the https: scheme (except on localhost),
and therefore is more resistant to man-in-the-middle attacks.

openid-connect.name: session_cookie_maxsize
openid-connect.description: The maximum size of each cookie chunk in bytes.

openid-connect.name: session_secret
openid-connect.default: (with database, or traditional mode, the value is auto-generated and stored along the issuer discovery information in the database)
openid-connect.description: The session secret.

openid-connect.name: disable_session
openid-connect.description:
Disable issuing the session cookie with the specified grants:
- `password`: do not start a session with the password grant
- `client_credentials`: do not start a session with the client credentials grant
- `authorization_code`: do not start a session after authorization code flow
- `bearer`: do not start session with JWT access token authentication
- `introspection`: do not start session with introspection authentication
- `userinfo`: do not start session with user info authentication
- `kong_oauth2`: do not start session with Kong OAuth authentication
- `refresh_token` do not start session with refresh token grant
- `session`: do not renew the session with session cookie authentication

openid-connect.name: session_strategy
openid-connect.description:
The session strategy:
- `default`:  reuses session identifiers over modifications (but can be problematic with single-page applications with a lot of concurrent asynchronous requests)
- `regenerate`: generates a new session identifier on each modification and does not use expiry for signature verification (useful in single-page applications or SPAs)

openid-connect.name: session_compressor
openid-connect.description:
The session strategy:
- `none`: no compression
- `zlib`: use zlib to compress cookie data

openid-connect.name: session_audience
openid-connect.description: The session audience, which is the intended target application. For example `"my-application"`.

openid-connect.name: session_remember
openid-connect.description: Enables or disables persistent sessions.

openid-connect.name: session_remember_cookie_name
openid-connect.description: Persistent session cookie name. Use with the `remember` configuration parameter.

openid-connect.name: session_remember_rolling_timeout
openid-connect.description: The persistent session rolling timeout window, in seconds.

openid-connect.name: session_remember_absolute_timeout
openid-connect.description: The persistent session absolute timeout limit, in seconds.

openid-connect.name: session_request_headers
openid-connect.description:
List of information to include, as headers, in the request to the upstream. 
Accepted values are: `id`, `audience`, `subject`, `timeout`, `idling-timeout`, `rolling-timeout`, and
`absolute-timeout`.
For example, `{ "id", "timeout" }` sets both `Session-Id` and `Session-Timeout` in the request headers.

openid-connect.name: session_response_headers
openid-connect.description:
List of information to include, as headers, in the response to the downstream. 
Accepted values are: `id`, `audience`, `subject`, `timeout`, `idling-timeout`, `rolling-timeout`, and
`absolute-timeout`.
For example: `{ "id", "timeout" }` injects both `Session-Id` and `Session-Timeout` in the response headers.

openid-connect.name: session_store_metadata
openid-connect.description:
Configures whether or not session metadata should be stored.
This metadata includes information about the active sessions for a specific audience
belonging to a specific subject.

openid-connect.name: session_enforce_same_subject
openid-connect.description: When set to `true`, audiences are forced to share the same subject.

openid-connect.name: session_hash_subject
openid-connect.description:
When set to `true`, the value of subject is hashed before being stored.
Only applies when `session_store_metadata` is enabled.

openid-connect.name: session_hash_storage_key
openid-connect.description:
When set to `true`, the storage key (session ID) is hashed for extra security.
Hashing the storage key means it is impossible to decrypt data from the storage
without a cookie.

openid-connect.name: session_storage
openid-connect.description:
The session storage for session data:
- `cookie`: stores session data with the session cookie (the session cannot be invalidated or revoked without changing session secret, but is stateless, and doesn't require a database)
- `memcache`: stores session data in memcached
- `redis`: stores session data in Redis

openid-connect.name: reverify
openid-connect.description: Specifies whether to always verify tokens stored in the session.

openid-connect.name: session_memcache_prefix
openid-connect.description: The memcached session key prefix.

openid-connect.name: session_memcached_prefix
openid-connect.description: The memcached session key prefix.

openid-connect.name: session_memcache_socket
openid-connect.description: The memcached unix socket path.

openid-connect.name: session_memcached_socket
openid-connect.description: The memcached unix socket path.

openid-connect.name: session_memcache_host
openid-connect.description: The memcached host.

openid-connect.name: session_memcached_host
openid-connect.description: The memcached host.

openid-connect.name: session_memcache_port
openid-connect.description: The memcached port.

openid-connect.name: session_memcached_port
openid-connect.description: The memcached port.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_prefix
openid-connect.description: The Redis session key prefix.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_socket
openid-connect.description: The Redis unix socket path.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_host
openid-connect.description: The Redis host

openid-connect.name: session_redis_port
openid-connect.description: The Redis port.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_username
openid-connect.description:
Username to use for Redis connection when the `redis` session storage is defined and ACL authentication is desired.
If undefined, ACL authentication will not be performed.

This requires Redis v6.0.0+. The username **cannot** be set to `default`.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_password
openid-connect.description:
Password to use for Redis connection when the `redis` session storage is defined.
If undefined, no AUTH commands are sent to Redis.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_auth
openid-connect.description:
Password to use for Redis connection when the `redis` session storage is defined.
If undefined, no AUTH commands are sent to Redis.

{:.important}
> In Kong Gateway 2.8.x, this field is deprecated and replaced with `session_redis_password`.
> The`session_redis_auth` field will continue to work in a backwards compatible way,
> but it is recommended to use the replacement field.
>
> Starting from Kong Gateway 3.0.0.0, this field has been removed.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_connect_timeout
openid-connect.description: The Redis connection timeout in milliseconds.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_read_timeout
openid-connect.description: The Redis read timeout in milliseconds.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_send_timeout
openid-connect.description: The Redis send timeout in milliseconds.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_ssl
openid-connect.description: Use SSL/TLS for Redis connection.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_ssl_verify
openid-connect.description: Verify Redis server certificate.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_server_name
openid-connect.description: The SNI used for connecting the Redis server.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_cluster_nodes
openid-connect.description:
The Redis cluster node host. Takes an array of host records, with
`ip` and `port` values.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_cluster_nodes
openid-connect.description:
The Redis cluster node host. Takes an array of host records, with
either `ip` or `host`, and `port` values.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_cluster_maxredirections
openid-connect.description: The Redis cluster maximum redirects.

openid-connect.name: session_redis_cluster_max_redirections
openid-connect.description: The Redis cluster maximum redirects.
Parameters normally not needed as the endpoints are discovered.

openid-connect.name: authorization_endpoint
openid-connect.description: The authorization endpoint.

openid-connect.name: token_endpoint
openid-connect.description: The token endpoint.

openid-connect.name: introspection_endpoint
openid-connect.description: The introspection endpoint.

openid-connect.name: revocation_endpoint
openid-connect.description: The revocation endpoint.

openid-connect.name: userinfo_endpoint
openid-connect.description: The user info endpoint.

openid-connect.name: end_session_endpoint
openid-connect.description: The end session endpoint.

openid-connect.name: token_exchange_endpoint
openid-connect.description: The token exchange endpoint.
Parameters normally not needed as the client authentication can be specified for the client.

openid-connect.name: token_endpoint_auth_method
openid-connect.description:
The token endpoint authentication method:
- `client_secret_basic`: send `client_id` and `client_secret` in `Authorization: Basic` header
- `client_secret_post`: send `client_id` and `client_secret` as part of the body
- `client_secret_jwt`: send client assertion signed with the `client_secret` as part of the body
- `private_key_jwt`:  send client assertion signed with the `private key` as part of the body
- `none`: do not authenticate

openid-connect.name: introspection_endpoint_auth_method
openid-connect.description:
The introspection endpoint authentication method:
- `client_secret_basic`: send `client_id` and `client_secret` in `Authorization: Basic` header
- `client_secret_post`: send `client_id` and `client_secret` as part of the body
- `client_secret_jwt`: send client assertion signed with the `client_secret` as part of the body
- `private_key_jwt`:  send client assertion signed with the `private key` as part of the body
- `none`: do not authenticate

openid-connect.name: revocation_endpoint_auth_method
openid-connect.description:
The revocation endpoint authentication method:
- `client_secret_basic`: send `client_id` and `client_secret` in `Authorization: Basic` header
- `client_secret_post`: send `client_id` and `client_secret` as part of the body
- `client_secret_jwt`: send client assertion signed with the `client_secret` as part of the body
- `private_key_jwt`:  send client assertion signed with the `private key` as part of the body
- `none`: do not authenticate

openid-connect.name: discovery_headers_names
openid-connect.description: Extra header names passed to the discovery endpoint.

openid-connect.name: discovery_headers_values
openid-connect.description: Extra header values passed to the discovery endpoint.

openid-connect.name: response_mode
openid-connect.description:
The response mode passed to the authorization endpoint:
- `query`: Instructs the identity provider to pass parameters in query string
- `form_post`: Instructs the identity provider to pass parameters in request body
- `fragment`: Instructs the identity provider to pass parameters in uri fragment (rarely useful as the plugin itself cannot read it)

openid-connect.name: response_type
openid-connect.description: The response type passed to the authorization endpoint.

openid-connect.name: scopes
openid-connect.description: The scopes passed to the authorization and token endpoints.

openid-connect.name: audience
openid-connect.description: The audience passed to the authorization endpoint.

openid-connect.name: redirect_uri
openid-connect.datatype: array of urls (one for each client)
openid-connect.description: The redirect URI passed to the authorization and token endpoints.

openid-connect.name: authorization_query_args_names
openid-connect.description: Extra query argument names passed to the authorization endpoint.

openid-connect.name: authorization_query_args_values
openid-connect.description: Extra query argument values passed to the authorization endpoint.

openid-connect.name: authorization_query_args_client
openid-connect.description: Extra query arguments passed from the client to the authorization endpoint.

openid-connect.name: token_headers_names
openid-connect.description: Extra header names passed to the token endpoint.

openid-connect.name: token_headers_values
openid-connect.description: Extra header values passed to the token endpoint.

openid-connect.name: token_headers_client
openid-connect.description: Extra headers passed from the client to the token endpoint.

openid-connect.name: token_post_args_names
openid-connect.description: Extra post argument names passed to the token endpoint.

openid-connect.name: token_post_args_values
openid-connect.description: Extra post argument values passed to the token endpoint.

openid-connect.name: token_post_args_client
openid-connect.description:
Pass extra arguments from the client to the OpenID-Connect plugin. If arguments exist, the client can pass them using:
- Request Body
- Query parameters

This parameter can be used with `scope` values, like this:

`config.token_post_args_client=scope`

In this case, the token would take the `scope` value from the query parameter or from the request body and send it to the token endpoint.
Parameters for an uncommon use case of sending certain token endpoint headers to the downstream client.

openid-connect.name: token_headers_replay
openid-connect.description: The names of token endpoint response headers to forward to the downstream client.

openid-connect.name: token_headers_prefix
openid-connect.description: Add a prefix to the token endpoint response headers before forwarding them to the downstream client.

openid-connect.name: token_headers_grants
openid-connect.description:
Enable the sending of the token endpoint response headers only with certain grants:
- `password`: with OAuth password grant
- `client_credentials`: with OAuth client credentials grant
- `authorization_code`: with authorization code flow
- `refresh_token` with refresh token grant

openid-connect.name: introspection_hint
openid-connect.description: Introspection hint parameter value passed to the introspection endpoint.

openid-connect.name: introspection_accept
openid-connect.description:
The value of `Accept` header for introspection requests:
- `application/json`: introspection response as JSON
- `application/token-introspection+jwt`: introspection response as JWT (from the current IETF draft document)
- `application/jwt`: introspection response as JWT (from the obsolete IETF draft document)

openid-connect.name: introspection_headers_names
openid-connect.description: Extra header names passed to the introspection endpoint.

openid-connect.name: introspection_headers_values
openid-connect.description: Extra header values passed to the introspection endpoint.

openid-connect.name: introspection_headers_client
openid-connect.description: Extra headers passed from the client to the introspection endpoint.

openid-connect.name: introspection_post_args_names
openid-connect.description: Extra post argument names passed to the introspection endpoint.

openid-connect.name: introspection_post_args_values
openid-connect.description: Extra post argument values passed to the introspection endpoint.

openid-connect.name: introspection_post_args_client
openid-connect.description: Extra post arguments passed from the client to the introspection endpoint.

openid-connect.name: userinfo_accept
openid-connect.description:
The value of `Accept` header for user info requests:
- `application/json`: user info response as JSON
- `application/jwt`: user info response as JWT (from the obsolete IETF draft document)

openid-connect.name: userinfo_headers_names
openid-connect.description: Extra header names passed to the user info endpoint.

openid-connect.name: userinfo_headers_values
openid-connect.description: Extra header values passed to the user info endpoint.

openid-connect.name: userinfo_headers_client
openid-connect.description: Extra headers passed from the client to the user info endpoint.

openid-connect.name: userinfo_query_args_names
openid-connect.description: Extra query argument names passed to the user info endpoint.

openid-connect.name: userinfo_query_args_values
openid-connect.description: Extra query argument values passed to the user info endpoint.

openid-connect.name: userinfo_query_args_client
openid-connect.description: Extra query arguments passed from the client to the user info endpoint.
Parameters for generic settings for the HTTP client when the plugin needs to interact with the identity provider.

openid-connect.name: keepalive
openid-connect.description: Use keepalive with the HTTP client.

openid-connect.name: ssl_verify
openid-connect.description: Verify identity provider server certificate.

openid-connect.name: timeout
openid-connect.description: Network IO timeout in milliseconds.

openid-connect.name: http_version
openid-connect.description:
The HTTP version used for the requests by this plugin:
- `1.1`: HTTP 1.1 (the default)
- `1.0`: HTTP 1.0
Parameters only needed if the HTTP(S) requests to identity provider need to go through a proxy server.

openid-connect.name: http_proxy
openid-connect.description: The HTTP proxy

openid-connect.name: http_proxy_authorization
openid-connect.description: The HTTP proxy authorization.

openid-connect.name: https_proxy
openid-connect.description: The HTTPS proxy

openid-connect.name: https_proxy_authorization
openid-connect.description: The HTTPS proxy authorization.

openid-connect.name: no_proxy
openid-connect.description: Do not use proxy with these hosts.
These do not apply to the discovery cache.

openid-connect.name: cache_ttl
openid-connect.description: The default cache ttl in seconds that is used in case the cached object does not specify the expiry.

openid-connect.name: cache_ttl_max
openid-connect.description: The maximum cache ttl in seconds (enforced).

openid-connect.name: cache_ttl_min
openid-connect.description: The minimum cache ttl in seconds (enforced).

openid-connect.name: cache_ttl_neg
openid-connect.description: The negative cache ttl in seconds.

openid-connect.name: cache_ttl_resurrect
openid-connect.description: The resurrection ttl in seconds.

openid-connect.name: cache_tokens
openid-connect.description: Cache the token endpoint requests.

openid-connect.name: cache_tokens_salt
openid-connect.description:
Salt used for generating the cache key that us used for caching the token
endpoint requests.
> If you use multiple plugin instances of the OpenID Connect
> plugin and want to share token endpoint caches between the plugin
> instances, set the salt to the same value on each plugin instance.

openid-connect.name: cache_introspection
openid-connect.description: Cache the introspection endpoint requests.

openid-connect.name: cache_token_exchange
openid-connect.description: Cache the token exchange endpoint requests.

openid-connect.name: cache_user_info
openid-connect.description: Cache the user info requests.

openid-connect.name: resolve_distributed_claims
openid-connect.description:
Distributed claims are represented by the `_claim_names` and `_claim_sources` members
of the JSON object containing the claims.
If this parameter is set to `true`, the plugin explicitly resolves these distributed claims.

opentelemetry.name: endpoint
opentelemetry.description:
The full HTTP(S) endpoint that Kong Gateway should send OpenTelemetry spans to.
The endpoint must be a [OTLP/HTTP](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-specification/blob/main/specification/protocol/otlp.md#otlphttp) endpoint.

opentelemetry.name: headers
opentelemetry.description:
The custom headers to be added in the HTTP request sent to the OTLP server.
This setting is useful for adding the authentication headers (token)
for the APM backend.

opentelemetry.name: headers
opentelemetry.description:
The custom headers to be added in the HTTP request sent to the OTLP server.
This setting is useful for adding the authentication headers (token)
for the APM backend.

opentelemetry.name: resource_attributes
opentelemetry.description:
The attributes specified on this property are added to the OpenTelemetry resource object.
Kong follows the OpenTelemetry specification for [Semantic Attributes](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-specification/blob/main/specification/resource/semantic_conventions/README.md#service).

The following attributes are automatically added to the resource object:
- `service.name`: The name of the service. This is `kong` by default.
- `service.version`: The version of Kong Gateway.
- `service.instance.id`: The node id of Kong Gateway.

The default values for the above attributes can be overridden by specifying them in this property. For example,
to override the default value of `service.name` to `my-service`, you can specify `{ "service.name": "my-service" }`.

opentelemetry.name: batch_span_count
opentelemetry.description: The number of spans to be sent in a single batch.
