opentelemetry.name: batch_flush_delay
opentelemetry.description: The delay, in seconds, between two consecutive batches.

opentelemetry.name: connect_timeout
opentelemetry.description: The timeout, in milliseconds, for the OTLP server connection.

opentelemetry.name: send_timeout
opentelemetry.description: The timeout, in milliseconds, for sending spans to the OTLP server.

opentelemetry.name: read_timeout
opentelemetry.description: The timeout, in milliseconds, for reading the response from the OTLP server.

openwhisk.name: action
openwhisk.description: Name of the `Action` to be invoked by the plugin.

openwhisk.name: service_token
openwhisk.description: The service token to access Openwhisk resources.

openwhisk.name: https_verify
openwhisk.description: Set to `true` to authenticate Openwhisk server.

openwhisk.name: https
openwhisk.description: Option to use HTTPS to connect with the OpenWhisk server.

openwhisk.name: result
openwhisk.description: Return only the result of the invoked `Action`.

openwhisk.name: timeout
openwhisk.description: Timeout in milliseconds before closing a connection to OpenWhisk server.

openwhisk.name: keepalive
openwhisk.description: Time in milliseconds for which an idle connection to OpenWhisk server lives before being closed.

prometheus.name: per_consumer
prometheus.description:
A boolean value that determines if per-consumer metrics should be
collected.
If enabled, the `kong_http_requests_total` and `kong_bandwidth_bytes`
metrics fill in the consumer label when available.

prometheus.name: status_code_metrics
prometheus.description:
A boolean value that determines if status code metrics should be
collected.
If enabled, `http_requests_total`, `stream_sessions_total` metrics will be exported.

prometheus.name: latency_metrics
prometheus.description:
A boolean value that determines if status code metrics should be
collected.
If enabled, `kong_latency_ms`, `upstream_latency_ms` and `request_latency_ms`
metrics will be exported.

prometheus.name: bandwidth_metrics
prometheus.description:
A boolean value that determines if status code metrics should be
collected.
If enabled, `bandwidth_bytes` and `stream_sessions_total` metrics will be exported.

prometheus.name: upstream_health_metrics
prometheus.description:
A boolean value that determines if status code metrics should be
collected.
If enabled, `upstream_target_health` metric will be exported.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: response_code
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
Upstream response status code considered cacheable. The integers must be a value
between 100 and 900.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: request_method
proxy-cache-advanced.description: Downstream request methods considered cacheable. Available options: `HEAD`, `GET`, `POST`, `PATCH`, `PUT`.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: content_type
proxy-cache-advanced.description: Upstream response content types considered cacheable. The plugin performs an **exact match** against each specified value; for example, if the upstream is expected to respond with a `application/json; charset=utf-8` content-type, the plugin configuration must contain said value or a `Bypass` cache status is returned.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: vary_headers
proxy-cache-advanced.description: Relevant headers considered for the cache key. If undefined, none of the headers are taken into consideration.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: vary_query_params
proxy-cache-advanced.description: Relevant query parameters considered for the cache key. If undefined, all params are taken into consideration.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: cache_ttl
proxy-cache-advanced.description: TTL in seconds of cache entities.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: cache_control
proxy-cache-advanced.description: When enabled, respect the Cache-Control behaviors defined in [RFC7234](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7234#section-5.2).

proxy-cache-advanced.name: storage_ttl
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
Number of seconds to keep resources in the storage backend. This value is independent
of `cache_ttl` or resource TTLs defined by Cache-Control behaviors.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: strategy
proxy-cache-advanced.description: The backing data store in which to hold cache entities. Accepted values are: `memory` and `redis`.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: memory.dictionary_name
proxy-cache-advanced.description: The name of the shared dictionary in which to hold cache entities when the memory strategy is selected. Note that this dictionary currently must be defined manually in the Kong Nginx template.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.host
proxy-cache-advanced.description: Host to use for Redis connection when the redis strategy is defined.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.port
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
Port to use for Redis connections when the `redis` strategy is defined. Must be a
value between 0 and 65535. Default: 6379.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.ssl
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
If set to `true`, then uses SSL to connect to Redis.

**Note:** This parameter is only available for Kong Gateway versions
2.2.x and later.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.ssl_verify
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
If set to `true`, then verifies the validity of the server SSL certificate. Note that you need to configure the
[lua_ssl_trusted_certificate](/gateway/latest/reference/configuration/#lua_ssl_trusted_certificate)
to specify the CA (or server) certificate used by your Redis server. You may also need to configure
[lua_ssl_verify_depth](/gateway/latest/reference/configuration/#lua_ssl_verify_depth) accordingly.

**Note:** This parameter is only available for Kong Gateway versions
2.2.x and later.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.server_name
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
Specifies the server name for the new TLS extension Server Name Indication (SNI) when connecting over SSL.

**Note:** This parameter is only available for Kong Gateway versions
2.2.x and later.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.timeout
proxy-cache-advanced.description: Connection timeout to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.password
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
Password to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined.
If undefined, no AUTH commands are sent to Redis.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.database
proxy-cache-advanced.description: Database to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.sentinel_master
proxy-cache-advanced.description: Sentinel master to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined. Defining this value implies using Redis Sentinel.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.sentinel_username
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
Sentinel username to authenticate with a Redis Sentinel instance.
If undefined, ACL authentication will not be performed. This requires Redis v6.2.0+.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.sentinel_password
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
Sentinel password to authenticate with a Redis Sentinel instance.
If undefined, no AUTH commands are sent to Redis Sentinels.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.sentinel_role
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
Sentinel role to use for Redis connections when the `redis` strategy is defined. Defining this value
implies using Redis Sentinel. Available options:  `master`, `slave`, `any`.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.sentinel_addresses
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
Sentinel addresses to use for Redis connections when the `redis` strategy is defined.
Defining this value implies using Redis Sentinel. Each string element must
be a hostname. The minimum length of the array is 1 element.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.cluster_addresses
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
Cluster addresses to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined.
Defining this value implies using Redis cluster. Each string element must
be a hostname. The minimum length of the array is 1 element.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.keepalive_backlog
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
If specified, limits the total number of opened connections for a pool. If the
connection pool is full, all connection queues beyond the maximum limit go into
the backlog queue. Once the backlog queue is full, subsequent connect operations
will fail and return `nil`. Queued connect operations resume once the number of
connections in the pool is less than `keepalive_pool_size`. Note that queued
connect operations are subject to set timeouts.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.keepalive_pool
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
The custom name of the connection pool. If not specified, the connection pool
name is generated from the string template `"<host>:<port>"` or `"<unix-socket-path>"`.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: redis.keepalive_pool_size
proxy-cache-advanced.description:
The size limit for every cosocket connection pool associated with every remote
server, per worker process. If no `keepalive_pool_size` is specified and no `keepalive_backlog`
is specified, no pool is created. If no `keepalive_pool_size` is specified and `keepalive_backlog`
is specified, then the pool uses the default value `30`.

proxy-cache-advanced.name: bypass_on_err
proxy-cache-advanced.description: Unhandled errors while trying to retrieve a cache entry (such as redis down) are resolved with `Bypass`, with the request going upstream.

proxy-cache.name: response_code
proxy-cache.description: Upstream response status code considered cacheable.

proxy-cache.name: content_type
proxy-cache.description: Upstream response content types considered cacheable. The plugin performs an **exact match** against each specified value; for example, if the upstream is expected to respond with a `application/json; charset=utf-8` content-type, the plugin configuration must contain said value or a `Bypass` cache status is returned.

proxy-cache.name: vary_headers
proxy-cache.description: Relevant headers considered for the cache key. If undefined, none of the headers are taken into consideration.

proxy-cache.name: vary_query_params
proxy-cache.description: Relevant query parameters considered for the cache key. If undefined, all params are taken into consideration.

proxy-cache.name: cache_ttl
proxy-cache.description: TTL, in seconds, of cache entities.

proxy-cache.name: cache_control
proxy-cache.description: When enabled, respect the Cache-Control behaviors defined in [RFC7234](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7234#section-5.2).

proxy-cache.name: storage_ttl
proxy-cache.description: Number of seconds to keep resources in the storage backend. This value is independent of `cache_ttl` or resource TTLs defined by Cache-Control behaviors.

proxy-cache.name: strategy
proxy-cache.description: The backing data store in which to hold cache entities. The only accepted value is `memory`.

proxy-cache.name: memory.dictionary_name
proxy-cache.description: The name of the shared dictionary in which to hold cache entities when the memory strategy is selected. Note that this dictionary currently must be defined manually in the Kong Nginx template.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: limit
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
One or more requests-per-window limits to apply. There must be a matching
number of window limits and sizes specified.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: window_size
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
One or more window sizes to apply a limit to (defined in seconds). There
must be a matching number of window limits and sizes specified.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: identifier
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
The type of identifier used to generate the rate limit key.
Defines the scope used to increment the rate limiting counters.
Can be `ip`, `credential`, `consumer`, `service`, `header`, or `path`.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: path
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Request path to use as the rate limit key when `config.identifier` is
configured with the value `path`. Ignored when `config.identifier` has any other value.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: header_name
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Header name to use as the rate limit key when `config.identifier` is
configured with the value `header`. Ignored when `config.identifier` is not `header`.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: dictionary_name
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
The shared dictionary where counters are stored. When the plugin is
configured to synchronize counter data externally (that is 
`config.strategy` is `cluster` or `redis` and `config.sync_rate` isn't
`-1`), this dictionary serves as a buffer to populate counters in the
data store on each synchronization cycle.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: sync_rate
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
How often to sync counter data to the central data store. A value of 0
results in synchronous behavior; a value of -1 ignores sync behavior
entirely and only stores counters in node memory. A value greater than
0 will sync the counters in the specified number of seconds. The minimum
allowed interval is 0.02 seconds (20ms).

rate-limiting-advanced.name: namespace
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
The rate limiting library namespace to use for this plugin instance. Counter data and sync configuration is isolated in each namespace. {:.important} > **Important**: If managing Kong Gateway with **declarative configuration** or running Kong Gateway in **DB-less mode**, set the `namespace` explicitly in your declarative configuration. >

> If not set, you will run into the following issues: * In DB-less mode, this field will be regenerated automatically on every configuration change. * If applying declarative configuration with decK, decK will automatically fail the update and require a `namespace` value.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: strategy
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
The rate-limiting strategy to use for retrieving and incrementing the
limits. Available values are:
- `cluster`: Counters are stored in the Kong datastore and shared across
   the nodes.
- `redis`: Counters are stored on a Redis server and shared
   across the nodes.
- `local`: Counters are stored locally in-memory on the node (same effect
   as setting `sync_rate` to `-1`).

In DB-less, hybrid mode, and Konnect, the `cluster` config strategy
is not supported.

For details on which strategy should be used, refer to the
[implementation considerations](/hub/kong-inc/rate-limiting/#implementation-considerations).

rate-limiting-advanced.name: strategy
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
The rate-limiting strategy to use for retrieving and incrementing the
limits. Available values are:
- `local`: Counters are stored locally in-memory on the node (same effect
   as setting `sync_rate` to `-1`).
- `cluster`: Counters are stored in the Kong datastore and shared across
   the nodes.
- `redis`: Counters are stored on a Redis server and shared
   across the nodes.

In DB-less, hybrid mode, and Konnect, the `cluster` config strategy
is not supported. 

From `3.0.0.0` onwards, Kong disallows
the plugin enablement if the strategy is `cluster` and `sync_rate` is `-1`
with DB-less or hybrid mode. From `3.2.0.0` onward, please
use a different strategy or set `sync_rate` to `-1`.

For details on which strategy should be used, refer to the
[implementation considerations](/hub/kong-inc/rate-limiting/#implementation-considerations).

rate-limiting-advanced.name: hide_client_headers
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Optionally hide informative response headers that would otherwise
provide information about the current status of limits and counters as
described in the paragraph [Headers sent to the client](#headers-sent-to-the-client).
Available options: `true` or `false`.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.host
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Host to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined.
This parameter accepts a hostname or an IP address as a value.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.port
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Specifies the Redis server port when using the `redis` strategy. Must be a
value between 0 and 65535. Default: 6379.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.ssl
rate-limiting-advanced.description: If set to true, then uses SSL to connect to Redis.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.ssl_verify
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
If set to true, then verifies the validity of the server SSL certificate. Note that you need to configure the
[lua_ssl_trusted_certificate](/gateway/latest/reference/configuration/#lua_ssl_trusted_certificate)
to specify the CA (or server) certificate used by your redis server. You may also need to configure
[lua_ssl_verify_depth](/gateway/latest/reference/configuration/#lua_ssl_verify_depth) accordingly.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.server_name
rate-limiting-advanced.description: Specifies the server name for the new TLS extension Server Name Indication (SNI) when connecting over SSL.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.timeout
rate-limiting-advanced.description: Connection timeout (in milliseconds) to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.timeout
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Connection timeout (in milliseconds) to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined.
This field is deprecated and replaced with `redis.connect_timeout`, `redis.send_timeout`, and `redis.read_timeout`.
The `redis.timeout` field will continue to work in a backwards compatible way, but it is recommended to use the replacement fields.
If set to something other than the default, a deprecation warning will be logged in the log file, stating the field's deprecation
and planned removal in v3.x.x.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.connect_timeout
rate-limiting-advanced.description: Connection timeout to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.send_timeout
rate-limiting-advanced.description: Send timeout to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.read_timeout
rate-limiting-advanced.description: Read timeout to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.username
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Username to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined and ACL authentication is desired.
If undefined, ACL authentication will not be performed.

This requires Redis v6.0.0+. The username **cannot** be set to `default`.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.password
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Password to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined.
If undefined, no AUTH commands are sent to Redis.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.database
rate-limiting-advanced.description: Database to use for Redis connection when the `redis` strategy is defined.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.sentinel_master
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Sentinel master to use for Redis connections when the `redis` strategy is defined.
Defining this value implies using Redis Sentinel.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.sentinel_username
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Sentinel username to authenticate with a Redis Sentinel instance.
If undefined, ACL authentication will not be performed. This requires Redis v6.2.0+.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.sentinel_password
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Sentinel password to authenticate with a Redis Sentinel instance.
If undefined, no AUTH commands are sent to Redis Sentinels.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.sentinel_role
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Sentinel role to use for Redis connections when the `redis` strategy is defined.
Defining this value implies using Redis Sentinel. Available options:  `master`, `slave`, `any`.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.sentinel_addresses
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Sentinel addresses to use for Redis connections when the `redis` strategy is defined.
Defining this value implies using Redis Sentinel. Each string element must
consist of a hostname (or IP address) and port. The minimum length of the array is 1 element.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.cluster_addresses
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Cluster addresses to use for Redis connections when the `redis` strategy is defined.
Defining this value implies using Redis cluster. Each string element must
consist of a hostname (or IP address) and port. The minimum length of the array is 1 element.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.keepalive_backlog
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
If specified, limits the total number of opened connections for a pool. If the
connection pool is full, all connection queues beyond the maximum limit go into
the backlog queue. Once the backlog queue is full, subsequent connect operations
will fail and return `nil`. Queued connect operations resume once the number of
connections in the pool is less than `keepalive_pool_size`. Note that queued
connect operations are subject to set timeouts.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.keepalive_pool
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
The custom name of the connection pool. If not specified, the connection pool
name is generated from the string template `"<host>:<port>"` or `"<unix-socket-path>"`.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: redis.keepalive_pool_size
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
The size limit for every cosocket connection pool associated with every remote
server, per worker process. If no `keepalive_pool_size` is specified and no `keepalive_backlog`
is specified, no pool is created. If no `keepalive_pool_size` is specified and `keepalive_backlog`
is specified, then the pool uses the default value `30`.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: window_type
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Sets the time window type to either `sliding` (default) or `fixed`.
Sliding windows apply the rate limiting logic while taking into account
previous hit rates (from the window that immediately precedes the current)
using a dynamic weight.
Fixed windows consist of buckets that are statically assigned to a
definitive time range, each request is mapped to only one fixed window
based on its timestamp and will affect only that window's counters.
For more information refer to the
[Enterprise Rate Limiting Library Overview](/gateway/latest/reference/rate-limiting/#overview).

rate-limiting-advanced.name: retry_after_jitter_max
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
The upper bound of a jitter (random delay) in seconds to be added to the `Retry-After`
header of denied requests (status = `429`) in order to prevent all the clients
from coming back at the same time. The lower bound of the jitter is `0`; in this case,
the `Retry-After` header is equal to the `RateLimit-Reset` header.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: enforce_consumer_groups
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
Set to `true` to enable `consumer_groups`, which allows the settings
from one of the allowed consumer groups to override the given plugin
configuration.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: consumer_groups
rate-limiting-advanced.description:
List of consumer groups allowed to override the rate limiting
settings for the given Route or Service. Required if
`enforce_consumer_groups` is set to `true`.

Flipping `enforce_consumer_groups` from `true` to `false` disables the
group override, but does not clear the list of consumer groups.
You can then flip `enforce_consumer_groups` to `true` to re-enforce the
groups.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: disable_penalty
rate-limiting-advanced.description: If set to `true`, this doesn't count denied requests (status = `429`). If set to `false`, all requests, including denied ones, are counted. This parameter only affects the `sliding` window_type.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: error_code
rate-limiting-advanced.description: Set a custom error code to return when the rate limit is exceeded.

rate-limiting-advanced.name: error_message
rate-limiting-advanced.description: Set a custom error message to return when the rate limit is exceeded.

rate-limiting.name: second
rate-limiting.description: The number of HTTP requests that can be made per second.

rate-limiting.name: minute
rate-limiting.description: The number of HTTP requests that can be made per minute.

rate-limiting.name: hour
rate-limiting.description: The number of HTTP requests that can be made per hour.

rate-limiting.name: day
rate-limiting.description: The number of HTTP requests that can be made per day.

rate-limiting.name: month
rate-limiting.description: The number of HTTP requests that can be made per month.

rate-limiting.name: year
rate-limiting.description: The number of HTTP requests that can be made per year.

rate-limiting.name: limit_by
rate-limiting.description:
The entity that is used when aggregating the limits. Available values are:
- `consumer`
- `credential`
- `ip`
- `service`
- `header` (The `header_name` configuration must be provided.)
- `path` (The `path` configuration must be provided.)

If the entity value for aggregating the limits cannot be determined, the system falls back to `ip`.

rate-limiting.name: header_name
rate-limiting.description: Header name to be used if `limit_by` is set to `header`.

rate-limiting.name: path
rate-limiting.description: Path to be used if `limit_by` is set to `path`.

rate-limiting.name: policy
rate-limiting.description:
The rate-limiting policies to use for retrieving and incrementing the
limits. Available values are:
- `local`: Counters are stored locally in-memory on the node.
- `cluster`: Counters are stored in the Kong data store and shared across
the nodes.
- `redis`: Counters are stored on a Redis server and shared
across the nodes.

In DB-less, hybrid mode, and Konnect, the `cluster` config policy is not supported.
For DB-less mode or Konnect, use one of `redis` or `local`; for hybrid mode, use
`redis`, or `local` for data planes only.

For details on which policy should be used, refer to the
[implementation considerations](#implementation-considerations).

rate-limiting.name: fault_tolerant
rate-limiting.description: A boolean value that determines if the requests should be proxied even if Kong has troubles connecting a third-party data store. If `true`, requests will be proxied anyway, effectively disabling the rate-limiting function until the data store is working again. If `false`, then the clients will see `500` errors.

rate-limiting.name: hide_client_headers
rate-limiting.description: Optionally hide informative response headers.

rate-limiting.name: redis_host
rate-limiting.description: When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies the address to the Redis server.

rate-limiting.name: redis_port
rate-limiting.description: When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies the port of the Redis server. By default is `6379`.

rate-limiting.name: redis_username
rate-limiting.description:
When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies the username to connect to the Redis server when ACL authentication is desired. 

This requires Redis v6.0.0+. The username **cannot** be set to `default`.

rate-limiting.name: redis_password
rate-limiting.description: When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies the password to connect to the Redis server.

rate-limiting.name: redis_ssl
rate-limiting.description: When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies if SSL is used to connect to the Redis server.

rate-limiting.name: redis_ssl_verify
rate-limiting.description: When using the `redis` policy with `redis_ssl` set to `true`, this property specifies it server SSL certificate is validated. Note that you need to configure the lua_ssl_trusted_certificate to specify the CA (or server) certificate used by your Redis server. You may also need to configure lua_ssl_verify_depth accordingly.

rate-limiting.name: redis_server_name
rate-limiting.description: When using the `redis` policy with `redis_ssl` set to `true`, this property specifies the server name for the TLS extension Server Name Indication (SNI)

rate-limiting.name: redis_timeout
rate-limiting.description: When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies the timeout in milliseconds of any command submitted to the Redis server.

rate-limiting.name: redis_database
rate-limiting.description: When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies the Redis database to use.

rate-limiting.name: error_code
rate-limiting.description: Set a custom error code to return when the rate limit is exceeded.

rate-limiting.name: error_message
rate-limiting.description: Set a custom error message to return when the rate limit is exceeded.

request-size-limiting.name: allowed_payload_size
request-size-limiting.description: Allowed request payload size in megabytes. Default is `128` megabytes (128000000 bytes).

request-size-limiting.name: size_unit
request-size-limiting.description: Size unit can be set either in `bytes`, `kilobytes`, or `megabytes` (default). This configuration is not available in versions prior to Kong Gateway 1.3 and Kong Gateway (OSS) 2.0.

request-size-limiting.name: require_content_length
request-size-limiting.description: Set to `true` to ensure a valid `Content-Length` header exists before reading the request body.

request-termination.name: status_code
request-termination.description: The response code to send. Must be an integer between 100 and 599.

request-termination.name: message
request-termination.value_in_examples: So long and thanks for all the fish!
request-termination.description: The message to send, if using the default response generator.

request-termination.name: body
request-termination.description: The raw response body to send. This is mutually exclusive with the `config.message` field.

request-termination.name: content_type
request-termination.description: Content type of the raw response configured with `config.body`.

request-termination.name: trigger
request-termination.description: When not set, the plugin always activates. When set to a string, the plugin will activate exclusively on requests containing either a header or a query parameter that is named the string.

request-termination.name: echo
request-termination.description: When set, the plugin will echo a copy of the request back to the client. The main usecase for this is debugging. It can be combined with `trigger` in order to debug requests on live systems without disturbing real traffic.

request-transformer-advanced.name: http_method
request-transformer-advanced.description: Changes the HTTP method for the upstream request.

request-transformer-advanced.name: remove.headers
request-transformer-advanced.description: List of header names. Unset the headers with the given name.

request-transformer-advanced.name: remove.querystring
request-transformer-advanced.description: List of querystring names. Remove the querystring if it is present.

request-transformer-advanced.name: remove.body
request-transformer-advanced.description:
List of parameter names. Remove the parameter if and only if content-type is one of the
following: [`application/json`, `multipart/form-data`, `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`]; and parameter is present.

request-transformer-advanced.name: replace.headers
request-transformer-advanced.description:
List of headername:value pairs. If and only if the header is already set,
replace its old value with the new one. Ignored if the header is not already set.

request-transformer-advanced.name: replace.querystring
request-transformer-advanced.description:
List of queryname:value pairs. If and only if the querystring name is already set,
replace its old value with the new one. Ignored if the header is not already set.

request-transformer-advanced.name: replace.uri
request-transformer-advanced.description:
Updates the upstream request URI with given value. This value can only
be used to update the path part of the URI; not the scheme, nor the hostname.

request-transformer-advanced.name: replace.body
replace.json_types
request-transformer-advanced.datatype: array of string, boolean, or number elements
request-transformer-advanced.description: List of JSON type names. Specify the types of the JSON values returned when replacing JSON properties.

request-transformer-advanced.name: rename.headers
request-transformer-advanced.description:
List of `headername:value` pairs. If and only if the header is already set,
rename the header. The value is unchanged. Ignored if the header is not already set.

request-transformer-advanced.name: rename.querystring
request-transformer-advanced.description:
List of `queryname:value` pairs. If and only if the field name is already set,
rename the field name. The value is unchanged. Ignored if the field name is not already set.

request-transformer-advanced.name: rename.body
request-transformer-advanced.description:
List of parameter `name:value` pairs. Rename the parameter name if and only if content-type is
one of the following: [`application/json`, `multipart/form-data`, `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`]; and parameter is present.

request-transformer-advanced.name: add.headers
request-transformer-advanced.description:
List of `headername:value` pairs. If and only if the header is not already set,
set a new header with the given value. Ignored if the header is already set.

request-transformer-advanced.name: add.querystring
request-transformer-advanced.description:
List of `queryname:value` pairs. If and only if the querystring name is not already set,
set a new querystring with the given value. Ignored if the querystring name is already set.

request-transformer-advanced.name: add.body
request-transformer-advanced.description:
List of `paramname:value` pairs. If and only if content-type is one the following: [`application/json, multipart/form-data`, `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`]; and the parameter is not present, add a new parameter with the given value to form-encoded body.
Ignored if the parameter is already present.

request-transformer-advanced.name: add.json_types
request-transformer-advanced.datatype: array of string, boolean, or number elements
request-transformer-advanced.description: List of JSON type names. Specify the types of the JSON values returned when adding a new JSON property.

request-transformer-advanced.name: append.headers
request-transformer-advanced.description:
List of `headername:value` pairs. If the header is not set, set it with the given value.
If it is already set, a new header with the same name and the new value will be set.

request-transformer-advanced.name: append.querystring
request-transformer-advanced.description:
List of `queryname:value` pairs. If the querystring is not set, set it with the given value.
If it is already set, a new querystring with the same name and the new value will be set.

request-transformer-advanced.name: append.body
request-transformer-advanced.description:
List of `paramname:value` pairs. If the content-type is one the following: [`application/json`, `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`]; add a new parameter with the given value if the parameter is not present. Otherwise, if it is already present,
the two values (old and new) will be aggregated in an array.

request-transformer-advanced.name: append.json_types
request-transformer-advanced.datatype: array of string, boolean, or number elements
request-transformer-advanced.description: List of JSON type names. Specify the types of the JSON values returned when appending JSON properties.

request-transformer-advanced.name: allow.body
request-transformer-advanced.description:
Set of parameter names. If and only if content-type is one the following:
[`application/json`, `multipart/form-data`, `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`]; allow only allowed parameters in the body.

request-transformer-advanced.name: dots_in_keys
request-transformer-advanced.description:
Specify whether dots (for example, `customers.info.phone`) should be treated as part of a property name or used to descend into nested JSON objects. 
See [Arrays and nested objects](#arrays-and-nested-objects).

request-transformer.name: http_method
request-transformer.description: Sets the HTTP method for the upstream request.

request-transformer.name: remove.headers
request-transformer.description: List of header names. Unset the headers with the given name.

request-transformer.name: remove.querystring
request-transformer.description: List of querystring names. Remove the querystring if it is present.

request-transformer.name: remove.body
request-transformer.description:
List of parameter names. Remove the parameter if and only if content-type is one the following:
[`application/json`, `multipart/form-data`, `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`] and the parameter is present.

request-transformer.name: replace.uri
request-transformer.description:
Updates the upstream request URI with a given value. This value can be used to update
only the path part of the URI, not the scheme or the hostname.

request-transformer.name: replace.body
request-transformer.description:
List of `paramname:value` pairs. If and only if content-type is one the following
[`application/json`, `multipart/form-data`, `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`] and the
parameter is already present, replace its old value with the new one. Ignored if
the parameter is not already present.

request-transformer.name: replace.headers
request-transformer.description:
List of `headername:value` pairs. If and only if the header is already set, replace
its old value with the new one. Ignored if the header is not already set.

request-transformer.name: replace.querystring
request-transformer.description:
List of `queryname:value pairs`. If and only if the field name is already set,
replace its old value with the new one. Ignored if the field name is not already set.

request-transformer.name: rename.headers
request-transformer.description:
List of `headername:value` pairs. If and only if the header is already set, rename
the header. The value is unchanged. Ignored if the header is not already set.

request-transformer.name: rename.querystring
request-transformer.description:
List of queryname:value pairs. If and only if the field name is already set, rename the field name.
The value is unchanged. Ignored if the field name is not already set.

request-transformer.name: rename.body
request-transformer.description:
List of `paramname:value` pairs. Rename the parameter name if and only if
content-type is one the following [`application/json`, `multipart/form-data`, `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`]
and the parameter is present.

request-transformer.name: add.headers
request-transformer.description:
List of `headername:value` pairs. If and only if the header is not already set, set a new header
with the given value. Ignored if the header is already set.

request-transformer.name: add.querystring
request-transformer.description:
List of `queryname:value` pairs. If and only if the querystring is not already set, set a new
querystring with the given value. Ignored if the querystring is already set.

request-transformer.name: add.body
request-transformer.description:
List of `paramname:value` pairs. If and only if content-type is one the
following [`application/json`, `multipart/form-data`, `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`]
and the parameter is not present, add a new parameter with the given value to the form-encoded
body. Ignored if the parameter is already present.

request-transformer.name: append.headers
request-transformer.description:
List of `headername:value` pairs. If the header is not set, set it with the given value.
If it is already set, an additional new header with the same name and the new value will be appended.

request-transformer.name: append.querystring
request-transformer.description: List of `queryname:value` pairs. If the querystring is not set, set it with the given value. If it is already set, a new querystring with the same name and the new value will be set.

request-transformer.name: append.body
request-transformer.description:
List of `paramname:value` pairs. If the content-type is one the following
[`application/json`, `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`], add a new parameter
with the given value if the parameter is not present. Otherwise, if it is already present,
aggregate the two values (old and new) in an array.

request-validator.name: body_schema
request-validator.description:
The request body schema specification. One of `body_schema` or `parameter_schema`
must be specified.

request-validator.name: allowed_content_types
request-validator.description:
List of allowed content types. The value can be configured with the `charset` parameter. For example, `application/json; charset=UTF-8`.
**Note:** Body validation is only done for `application/json` and skipped for any other allowed content types. Only one parameter is supported at the most. If a request is sending more than one parameter with the Content-Type header, only the first parameter is evaluated and the rest are truncated. Note that `application/json` doesn't match with `application/json; charset=UTF-8`. The type, subtype, parameter names, and the value of the charset parameter are not case sensitive based on the RFC explanation.

request-validator.name: version
request-validator.description:
Which validator to use. Supported values are `kong` (default) for using Kong's own schema
validator, or `draft4` for using a JSON Schema Draft 4-compliant validator.

request-validator.name: parameter_schema
request-validator.description:
Array of parameter validator specifications. For details and examples, see
[Parameter Schema Definition](#parameter-schema-definition). One of `body_schema` or `parameter_schema`
must be specified.

request-validator.name: verbose_response
request-validator.description:
If enabled, the plugin returns more verbose and detailed validation errors
(for example, the name of the required field that is missing).

response-ratelimiting.name: limits.{limit_name}
response-ratelimiting.description: This is a list of custom objects that you can set, with arbitrary names set in the `{limit_name`} placeholder, like `config.limits.sms.minute=20` if your object is called "SMS".

response-ratelimiting.name: limits.{limit_name}.second
response-ratelimiting.description: The amount of HTTP requests the developer can make per second. At least one limit must exist.

response-ratelimiting.name: limits.{limit_name}.minute
response-ratelimiting.description: The amount of HTTP requests the developer can make per minute. At least one limit must exist.

response-ratelimiting.name: limits.{limit_name}.hour
response-ratelimiting.description: The amount of HTTP requests the developer can make per hour. At least one limit must exist.

response-ratelimiting.name: limits.{limit_name}.day
response-ratelimiting.description: The amount of HTTP requests the developer can make per day. At least one limit must exist.

response-ratelimiting.name: limits.{limit_name}.month
response-ratelimiting.description: The number of HTTP requests the developer can make per month. A month is defined as a 30-day interval of time, not a calendar month. At least one limit must exist.

response-ratelimiting.name: limits.{limit_name}.year
response-ratelimiting.description: The number of HTTP requests the developer can make per year. A year is defined as a 365-day interval of time, not a calendar year. At least one limit must exist.

response-ratelimiting.name: header_name
response-ratelimiting.description: The name of the response header used to increment the counters.

response-ratelimiting.name: block_on_first_violation
response-ratelimiting.description: A boolean value that determines if the requests should be blocked as soon as one limit is being exceeded. This will block requests that are supposed to consume other limits too.

response-ratelimiting.name: limit_by
response-ratelimiting.description: The entity that will be used when aggregating the limits: `consumer`, `credential`, `ip`. If the `consumer` or the `credential` cannot be determined, the system will always fallback to `ip`.

response-ratelimiting.name: policy
response-ratelimiting.description:
The rate-limiting policies to use for retrieving and incrementing the
limits. Available values are:
- `local`: Counters are stored locally in-memory on the node.
- `cluster`: Counters are stored in the Kong datastore and shared across
the nodes.
- `redis`: Counters are stored on a Redis server and shared
across the nodes.

In DB-less, hybrid mode, and Konnect, the `cluster` config policy is not supported.
For DB-less mode or Konnect, use one of `redis` or `local`; for hybrid mode, use
`redis`, or `local` for data planes only.

For details on which policy should be used, refer to the
[implementation considerations](/hub/kong-inc/rate-limiting/#implementation-considerations).

response-ratelimiting.name: fault_tolerant
response-ratelimiting.description: A boolean value that determines if the requests should be proxied even if Kong has troubles connecting a third-party datastore. If `true`, requests will be proxied anyway, effectively disabling the rate-limiting function until the datastore is working again. If `false`, then the clients will see `500` errors.

response-ratelimiting.name: hide_client_headers
response-ratelimiting.description: Optionally hide informative response headers.

response-ratelimiting.name: redis_host
response-ratelimiting.description: When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies the address to the Redis server.

response-ratelimiting.name: redis_port
response-ratelimiting.description: When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies the port of the Redis server.

response-ratelimiting.name: redis_username
response-ratelimiting.description:
When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies the username to connect to the Redis server when ACL authentication is desired.

This requires Redis v6.0.0+. The username **cannot** be set to `default`.

response-ratelimiting.name: redis_password
response-ratelimiting.description: When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies the password to connect to the Redis server.

response-ratelimiting.name: redis_timeout
response-ratelimiting.description: When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies the timeout in milliseconds of any command submitted to the Redis server.

response-ratelimiting.name: redis_database
response-ratelimiting.description: When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies Redis database to use.

response-ratelimiting.name: redis_ssl
response-ratelimiting.description: When using the `redis` policy, this property specifies if SSL is used to connect to the Redis server.

response-ratelimiting.name: redis_ssl_verify
response-ratelimiting.description: When using the `redis` policy with `redis_ssl` set to `true`, this property specifies if the server SSL certificate is validated. Note that you need to configure the `lua_ssl_trusted_certificate` to specify the CA (or server) certificate used by your Redis server. You may also need to configure `lua_ssl_verify_depth` accordingly.

response-ratelimiting.name: redis_server_name
response-ratelimiting.description: When using the `redis` policy with `redis_ssl` set to `true`, this property specifies the server name for the TLS extension Server Name Indication (SNI)

response-transformer-advanced.name: remove.headers
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of `headername[:value]`. If only `headername` is given, unset the header field with the given `headername`. If `headername:value` is given, unset the header field `headername` when it has a specific `value`. If `value` starts and ends with a `/` (slash character), then it is considered to be a regular expression. Note that in accordance with [RFC 7230](https://httpwg.org/specs/rfc7230.html#field.order) multiple header values with the same header name are allowed if the entire field value for that header field is defined as a comma-separated list or the header field is a `Set-Cookie` header field.

response-transformer-advanced.name: remove.json
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of property names. Remove the property from the JSON body if it is present.

response-transformer-advanced.name: remove.if_status
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of response status codes or status code ranges to which the transformation will apply. Empty means all response codes.

response-transformer-advanced.name: rename.headers
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of `headername1:headername2` pairs. If a header with `headername1` exists and `headername2` is valid, rename header to `headername2`.

response-transformer-advanced.name: rename.if_status
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of response status codes or status code ranges to which the transformation will apply. Empty means all response codes.

response-transformer-advanced.name: replace.headers
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of `headername:value` pairs. If and only if the header is already set, replace its old value with the new one. Ignored if the header is not already set.

response-transformer-advanced.name: replace.json
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of property `name:value` pairs. If and only if the parameter is already present, replace its old value with the new one. Ignored if the parameter is not already present.

response-transformer-advanced.name: replace.json_types
response-transformer-advanced.datatype: array of string, boolean, or number elements
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of JSON type names. Specify the types of the JSON values returned when replacing JSON properties.

response-transformer-advanced.name: replace.body
response-transformer-advanced.description: String with which to replace the entire response body.

response-transformer-advanced.name: replace.if_status
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of response status codes or status code ranges to which the transformation will apply. Empty means all response codes.

response-transformer-advanced.name: add.headers
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of `headername:value` pairs. If and only if the header is not already set, set a new header with the given value. Ignored if the header is already set.

response-transformer-advanced.name: add.json
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of `name:value` pairs. If and only if the property is not present, add a new property with the given value to the JSON body. Ignored if the property is already present.

response-transformer-advanced.name: add.json_types
response-transformer-advanced.datatype: array of string, boolean, or number elements
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of JSON type names. Specify the types of the JSON values returned when adding a new JSON property.

response-transformer-advanced.name: add.if_status
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of response status codes or status code ranges to which the transformation will apply. Empty means all response codes.

response-transformer-advanced.name: append.headers
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of `headername:value` pairs. If the header is not set, set it with the given value. If it is already set, a new header with the same name and the new value will be set.

response-transformer-advanced.name: append.json
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of `name:value` pairs. If the property is not present in the JSON body, add it with the given value. If it is already present, the two values (old and new) will be aggregated in an array.

response-transformer-advanced.name: append.json_types
response-transformer-advanced.datatype: array of string, boolean, or number elements
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of JSON type names. Specify the types of the JSON values returned when appending JSON properties.

response-transformer-advanced.name: append.if_status
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of response status codes or status code ranges to which the transformation will apply. Empty means all response codes.

response-transformer-advanced.name: allow.json
response-transformer-advanced.description: Set of parameter names. Only allowed parameters are present in the JSON response body.

response-transformer-advanced.name: transform.functions
response-transformer-advanced.description: Set of Lua functions to perform arbitrary transforms in a response JSON body.

response-transformer-advanced.name: transform.if_status
response-transformer-advanced.description: List of response status codes or ranges to which the arbitrary transformation applies. Leaving empty implies that the transformations apply to all response codes.

response-transformer-advanced.name: transform.json
response-transformer-advanced.description: Apply Lua functions to a particular list of JSON property `name` or `name:value` pairs.

response-transformer-advanced.name: dots_in_keys
response-transformer-advanced.description: Whether dots (for example, `customers.info.phone`) should be treated as part of a property name or used to descend into nested JSON objects. See [Arrays and nested objects](#arrays-and-nested-objects).

response-transformer.name: remove.headers
response-transformer.description: List of header names. Unset the header(s) with the given name.

response-transformer.name: remove.json
response-transformer.description: List of property names. Remove the property from the JSON body if it is present.

response-transformer.name: rename.headers
response-transformer.description: List of `original_header_name:new_header_name` pairs. If the header `original_headername` is already set, rename it to `new_headername`. Ignored if the header is not already set.

response-transformer.name: replace.headers
response-transformer.description: List of `headername:value` pairs. If and only if the header is already set, replace its old value with the new one. Ignored if the header is not already set.

response-transformer.name: replace.json
response-transformer.description: List of `property:value` pairs. If and only if the parameter is already present, replace its old value with the new one. Ignored if the parameter is not already present.

response-transformer.name: replace.json_types
response-transformer.description:
List of JSON type names. Specify the types of the JSON values returned when
replacing JSON properties. Each string
element can be one of: boolean, number, or string.

response-transformer.name: add.headers
response-transformer.description: List of `headername:value` pairs. If and only if the header is not already set, set a new header with the given value. Ignored if the header is already set.

response-transformer.name: add.json
response-transformer.description: List of `property:value` pairs. If and only if the property is not present, add a new property with the given value to the JSON body. Ignored if the property is already present.

response-transformer.name: add.json_types
response-transformer.description:
List of JSON type names. Specify the types of the JSON values returned when adding
a new JSON property. Each string element can be one of: boolean, number, or string.

response-transformer.name: append.headers
response-transformer.description:
List of `headername:value` pairs. If the header is not set, set it with the given value. If it is
already set, a new header with the same name and the new value will be set. Each string
element can be one of: boolean, number, or string.

response-transformer.name: append.json
response-transformer.description: List of `property:value` pairs. If the property is not present in the JSON body, add it with the given value. If it is already present, the two values (old and new) will be aggregated in an array.

response-transformer.name: append.json_types
response-transformer.description:
List of JSON type names. Specify the types of the JSON values returned when appending
JSON properties. Each string element can be one of: boolean, number, or string.

route-transformer-advanced.name: path
route-transformer-advanced.description: Updates the upstream request path with given value/template. This value can only be used to update the path part of the URI, not the scheme, nor the hostname. One of `config.path` or `config.host` or `config.port` must be specified.

route-transformer-advanced.name: host
route-transformer-advanced.description: Updates the upstream request Host with given value/template. This value can only be used to update the routing, it will not update the Host-header value. One of `config.path` or `config.host` or `config.port` must be specified.

route-transformer-advanced.name: port
route-transformer-advanced.description: Updates the upstream request Port with given value/template. Note that the port as set may be overridden again by DNS resolution (in case of SRV records,or an Upstream) One of `config.path` or `config.host` or `config.port` must be specified.

route-transformer-advanced.name: escape_path
route-transformer-advanced.description: If set to true, the path is escaped after being transformed.

saml.name: anonymous
saml.description: An optional string (consumer UUID or username) value to use as an “anonymous” consumer. If not set, a Kong Consumer must exist for the SAML IdP user credentials, mapping the username format to the Kong Consumer username.

saml.name: assertion_consumer_path
saml.description: The relative path the SAML IdP provider uses when responding with an authentication response.

saml.name: idp_sso_url
saml.description: The Single Sign-On URL exposed by the IdP provider. This is where SAML requests are posted. The IdP provides this information.

saml.name: idp_certificate
saml.description:
The public certificate provided by the IdP. This is used to validate responses from the IdP.

Only include the contents of the certificate. Do not include the header (`BEGIN CERTIFICATE`) and footer (`END CERTIFICATE`) lines.

saml.name: encryption_key
saml.description: The private encryption key required to decrypt encrypted assertions.

saml.name: request_signing_key
saml.description:
The private key for signing requests.  If this parameter is
set, requests sent to the IdP are signed.  The
`request_signing_certificate` parameter must be set as well.

saml.name: request_signing_certificate
saml.description: The certificate for signing requests.

saml.name: request_signature_algorithm
saml.description:
The signature algorithm for signing Authn requests. Options available are:
- `SHA256`
- `SHA384`
- `SHA512`

saml.name: request_digest_algorithm
saml.description:
The digest algorithm for Authn requests:
- `SHA256`
- `SHA1`

saml.name: response_signature_algorithm
saml.description:
The algorithm for validating signatures in SAML responses. Options available are:
- `SHA256`
- `SHA384`
- `SHA512`

saml.name: response_digest_algorithm
saml.description:
The algorithm for verifying digest in SAML responses:
- `SHA256`
- `SHA1`

saml.name: issuer
saml.description: The unique identifier of the IdP application. Formatted as a URL containing information about the IdP so the SP can validate that the SAML assertions it receives are issued from the correct IdP.

saml.name: nameid_format
saml.description:
The requested `NameId` format. Options available are:
- `Unspecified`
- `EmailAddress`
- `Persistent`
- `Transient`

saml.name: validate_assertion_signature
saml.description: Enable signature validation for SAML responses.
Parameters used with session cookie authentication.

saml.name: session_cookie_name
saml.description: The session cookie name.

saml.name: session_cookie_lifetime
saml.description: The session cookie lifetime in seconds.

saml.name: session_rolling_timeout
saml.description:
The session cookie rolling timeout in seconds.
Specifies how long the session can be used until it needs to be renewed.

saml.name: session_absolute_timeout
saml.description:
The session cookie absolute timeout in seconds.
Specifies how long the session can be used until it is no longer valid.

saml.name: session_cookie_idletime
saml.description: The session cookie idle time in seconds.

saml.name: session_idling_timeout
saml.description: The session cookie idle time in seconds.

saml.name: session_cookie_renew
saml.description: The session cookie renew time in seconds.

saml.name: session_cookie_path
saml.description: The session cookie path flag.

saml.name: session_cookie_domain
saml.description: The session cookie domain flag.

saml.name: session_cookie_samesite
saml.description:
Controls whether a cookie is sent with cross-origin requests, providing some protection against cross-site request forgery attacks:
- `Strict`: Cookies will only be sent in a first-party context and not be sent along with requests initiated by third party websites.
- `Lax`: Cookies are not sent on normal cross-site subrequests, like loading images or frames into a third party site, but are sent when a user is navigating to the origin site, like when they are following a link.
- `None`: Cookies will be sent in all contexts, including responses to both first-party and cross-origin requests. If `SameSite=None` is set, the cookie secure attribute must also be set or the cookie will be blocked.
- `off`: Do not set the Same-Site flag.

saml.name: session_cookie_same_site
saml.description:
Controls whether a cookie is sent with cross-origin requests, providing some protection against cross-site request forgery attacks:
- `Strict`: Cookies will only be sent in a first-party context and aren't sent along with requests initiated by third party websites.
- `Lax`: Cookies are not sent on normal cross-site subrequests, like loading images or frames into a third party site, but are sent when a user is navigating to the origin site, like when they are following a link.
- `None`: Cookies will be sent in all contexts, including responses to both first party and cross-origin requests. If `SameSite=None` is set, the cookie secure attribute must also be set or the cookie will be blocked.
- `Default`: Do not explicitly specify a Same-Site attribute.

saml.name: session_cookie_httponly
saml.description: Forbids JavaScript from accessing the cookie, for example, through the `Document.cookie` property.

saml.name: session_cookie_http_only
saml.description: Forbids JavaScript from accessing the cookie, for example, through the `Document.cookie` property.

saml.name: session_cookie_secure
saml.description:
The cookie is only sent to the server when a request is made with the https:scheme (except on localhost),
and therefore is more resistant to man-in-the-middle attacks.

saml.name: session_cookie_maxsize
saml.description: The maximum size of each cookie in bytes.

saml.name: session_secret
saml.description:
The session secret. This must be a random string of 32
characters from the base64 alphabet (letters, numbers, `/`, `_`
and `+`). It is used as the secret key for encrypting session
data as well as state information that is sent to the IdP in
the authentication exchange.

saml.name: session_strategy
saml.description:
The session strategy:
- `default`:  reuses session identifiers over modifications (but can be problematic with single-page applications with a lot of concurrent asynchronous requests)
- `regenerate`: generates a new session identifier on each modification and does not use expiry for signature verification. This is useful in single-page applications or SPAs.

saml.name: session_compressor
saml.description:
The session strategy:
- `none`: no compression.
- `zlib`: use Zlib to compress cookie data.

saml.name: session_audience
saml.description: The session audience, for example "my-application"

saml.name: session_remember
saml.description: Enables or disables persistent sessions

saml.name: session_remember_cookie_name
saml.description: Persistent session cookie name

saml.name: session_remember_rolling_timeout
saml.description: Persistent session rolling timeout in seconds.

saml.name: session_remember_absolute_timeout
saml.description: Persistent session absolute timeout in seconds.

saml.name: session_request_headers
saml.description:
List of information to include (as headers) in the request to upstream. 
Accepted values are: `id`, `audience`, `subject`, `timeout`, `idling-timeout`, `rolling-timeout`, and
`absolute-timeout`.
For example, { "id", "timeout" } will set both `Session-Id` and `Session-Timeout` in the request headers.

saml.name: session_response_headers
saml.description:
List of information to include (as headers) in the response to downstream. 
Accepted values are: `id`, `audience`, `subject`, `timeout`, `idling-timeout`, `rolling-timeout`, and
`absolute-timeout`.
For example: { "id", "timeout" } will inject both `Session-Id` and `Session-Timeout` in the response headers.

saml.name: session_store_metadata
saml.description:
Configures whether or not session metadata should be stored.
This includes information about the active sessions for the `specific_audience`
belonging to a specific subject.

saml.name: session_enforce_same_subject
saml.description: When set to `true`, audiences are forced to share the same subject.

saml.name: session_hash_subject
saml.description:
When set to `true`, the value of subject is hashed before being stored.
Only applies when `session_store_metadata` is enabled.

saml.name: session_hash_storage_key
saml.description:
When set to `true`, the storage key (session ID) is hashed for extra security.
Hashing the storage key means it is impossible to decrypt data from the storage
without a cookie.

saml.name: session_storage
saml.description:
The session storage for session data:
- `cookie`: stores session data with the session cookie. The session cannot be invalidated or revoked without changing the session secret, but is stateless, and doesn't require a database.
- `memcached`: stores session data in memcached
- `redis`: stores session data in Redis

saml.name: reverify
saml.description: Specifies whether to always verify tokens stored in the session.

saml.name: session_memcache_prefix
saml.description: The memcached session key prefix.

saml.name: session_memcached_prefix
saml.description: The memcached session key prefix.

saml.name: session_memcache_socket
saml.description: The memcached unix socket path.

saml.name: session_memcached_socket
saml.description: The memcached unix socket path.

saml.name: session_memcache_host
saml.description: The memcached host.

saml.name: session_memcached_host
saml.description: The memcached host.

saml.name: session_memcache_port
saml.description: The memcached port.

saml.name: session_memcached_port
saml.description: The memcached port.

saml.name: session_redis_prefix
saml.description: The Redis session key prefix.

saml.name: session_redis_socket
saml.description: The Redis unix socket path.

saml.name: session_redis_host
saml.description: The Redis host IP.

saml.name: session_redis_port
saml.description: The Redis port.

saml.name: session_redis_username
saml.description:
Redis username if the `redis` session storage is defined and ACL authentication is desired.
If undefined, ACL authentication will not be performed.

This requires Redis v6.0.0+. The username **cannot** be set to `default`.

saml.name: session_redis_password
saml.description:
Password to use for Redis connection when the `redis` session storage is defined.
If undefined, no auth commands are sent to Redis. This value is pulled from

saml.name: session_redis_connect_timeout
saml.description: The Redis connection timeout in milliseconds.

saml.name: session_redis_read_timeout
saml.description: The Redis read timeout in milliseconds.

saml.name: session_redis_send_timeout
saml.description: The Redis send timeout in milliseconds.

saml.name: session_redis_ssl
saml.description: Use SSL/TLS for the Redis connection.

saml.name: session_redis_ssl_verify
saml.description: Verify the Redis server certificate.

saml.name: session_redis_server_name
saml.description: The SNI used for connecting to the Redis server.

saml.name: session_redis_cluster_nodes
saml.description:
The Redis cluster node host. Takes an array of host records, with
either `ip` or `host`, and `port` values.

saml.name: session_redis_cluster_maxredirections
saml.description: The Redis cluster's maximum redirects.

saml.name: session_redis_cluster_max_redirections
saml.description: The Redis cluster maximum redirects.

serverless-functions.name: functions
serverless-functions.description:
*Deprecated*. Use `config.access` instead.

Array of stringified Lua code to be cached and run in sequence during access phase.

serverless-functions.name: certificate
serverless-functions.description:
Array of stringified Lua code to be cached and run in sequence during the certificate phase.

*Note*: This only runs on global plugins.

serverless-functions.name: rewrite
serverless-functions.description:
Array of stringified Lua code to be cached and run in sequence during the rewrite phase.

*Note*: This only runs on global plugins.

serverless-functions.name: access
serverless-functions.description: Array of stringified Lua code to be cached and run in sequence during the access phase.

serverless-functions.name: header_filter
serverless-functions.description: Array of stringified Lua code to be cached and run in sequence during the header_filter phase.

serverless-functions.name: body_filter
serverless-functions.description: Array of stringified Lua code to be cached and run in sequence during the body_filter phase.

serverless-functions.name: log
serverless-functions.description: Array of stringified Lua code to be cached and run in sequence during the log phase.

session.name: secret
session.description: The secret that is used in keyed HMAC generation.​

session.name: audience
session.description: The session audience, which is the intended target application. For example `"my-application"`.

session.name: remember
session.description: Enables or disables persistent sessions.

session.name: remember_cookie_name
session.description: Persistent session cookie name. Use with the `remember` configuration parameter.

session.name: remember_rolling_timeout
session.description: The persistent session rolling timeout window, in seconds.

session.name: remember_absolute_timeout
session.description: The persistent session absolute timeout limit, in seconds.

session.name: request_headers
session.description:
List of information to include, as headers, in the request to the upstream.

Accepted values are: `id`, `audience`, `subject`, `timeout`, `idling-timeout`, `rolling-timeout`, and
`absolute-timeout`.

For example, `{ "id", "timeout" }` sets both `Session-Id` and `Session-Timeout` in the request headers.

session.name: response_headers
session.description:
List of information to include, as headers, in the response to the downstream.

Accepted values are: `id`, `audience`, `subject`, `timeout`, `idling-timeout`, `rolling-timeout`, and
`absolute-timeout`.

For example: `{ "id", "timeout" }` injects both `Session-Id` and `Session-Timeout` in the response headers.

session.name: cookie_name
session.description: The name of the cookie.

session.name: cookie_lifetime
session.description: The duration in seconds that the session will remain open.

session.name: rolling_timeout
session.description:
The session cookie rolling timeout, in seconds.
Specifies how long the session can be used until it needs to be renewed.

session.name: absolute_timeout
session.description:
The session cookie absolute timeout, in seconds.
Specifies how long the session can be used until it is no longer valid.

session.name: cookie_idletime
session.description:
The cookie idle time (in seconds); if a cookie is not used for this time
period, the session becomes invalid. This value is not set by default,
meaning idle time checks are disabled.

session.name: idling_timeout
session.description: The session cookie idle time, in seconds.

session.name: cookie_renew
session.description: The remaining duration in seconds of a session at which point the Plugin renews the session.

session.name: cookie_path
session.description: The resource in the host where the cookie is available.

session.name: cookie_domain
session.default: Set using Nginx variable host, but may be overridden
session.description: The domain with which the cookie is intended to be exchanged.

session.name: cookie_samesite
session.description:
Determines whether and how a cookie may be sent with cross-site requests. 

* `Strict`: The browser sends cookies only if the request originated from the website that set the cookie.
* `Lax`: Same-site cookies are withheld on cross-domain subrequests, but are sent when a user navigates
to the URL from an external site, for example, by following a link. 
* `None` or `off`: Disables the same-site attribute so that a cookie may be sent with cross-site requests. 
`None` requires the Secure attribute (`cookie_secure`) in latest browser versions. For more information, 
see the [SameSite cookies docs on MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Set-Cookie/SameSite).

session.name: cookie_same_site
session.description:
Determines whether and how a cookie may be sent with cross-site requests.

* `Strict`: The browser sends cookies only if the request originated from the website that set the cookie.
* `Lax`: Same-site cookies are withheld on cross-domain subrequests, but are sent when a user navigates
to the URL from an external site, for example, by following a link. 
* `None` or `off`: Disables the same-site attribute so that a cookie may be sent with cross-site requests. 
`None` requires the Secure attribute (`cookie_secure`) in latest browser versions. For more info, see the
[SameSite cookies docs on MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Set-Cookie/SameSite).

session.name: cookie_httponly
session.description:
Applies the `HttpOnly` tag so that the cookie is sent only to a server. See the
[Restrict access to cookies docs on MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Cookies#Restrict_access_to_cookies).

session.name: cookie_http_only
session.description:
Applies the `HttpOnly` tag so that the cookie is sent only to a server. See the
[Restrict access to cookies docs on MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Cookies#Restrict_access_to_cookies).

session.name: cookie_secure
session.description:
Applies the Secure directive so that the cookie may be sent to the server only with an encrypted
request over the HTTPS protocol. See the
[Restrict access to cookies docs on MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Cookies#Restrict_access_to_cookies).

session.name: cookie_discard
session.description: The duration in seconds after which an old session’s TTL is updated that an old cookie is discarded.

session.name: stale_ttl
session.description:
The duration, in seconds, after which an old cookie is discarded, starting from the moment
when the session becomes outdated and is replaced by a new one.

session.name: cookie_persistent
session.description:
Allows the browser to persist cookies even if the browser is closed.
By default, cookies are not persisted across browser restarts.

session.name: storage
session.description:
Determines where the session data is stored. `kong`: Stores encrypted session data into Kong's current database
strategy; the cookie will not contain any session data. `cookie`: Stores encrypted
session data within the cookie itself.

session.name: logout_methods
session.description: The methods that may be used to end sessions: POST, DELETE, GET.

session.name: logout_query_arg
session.description: The query argument passed to logout requests.

session.name: logout_post_arg
session.description: The POST argument passed to logout requests. Do not change this property.

statsd-advanced.name: host
statsd-advanced.description: The IP address or hostname of the StatsD server.

statsd-advanced.name: port
statsd-advanced.description: The port of the StatsD server.

statsd-advanced.name: metrics
statsd-advanced.description: List of Metrics to be logged. Available values are described under [Metrics](#metrics).

statsd-advanced.name: prefix
statsd-advanced.description: String to prefix to each metric's name.

statsd-advanced.name: hostname_in_prefix
statsd-advanced.description: Include the `hostname` in the `prefix` for each metric name.

statsd-advanced.name: udp_packet_size
statsd-advanced.description:
Combine UDP packet up to the size configured. If zero (0), don't combine the
UDP packet. Must be a number between 0 and 65507 (inclusive).

statsd-advanced.name: allow_status_codes
statsd-advanced.default: All responses are passed to log metrics.
statsd-advanced.description: List of status code ranges that are allowed to be logged in metrics.

statsd-advanced.name: consumer_identifier_default
statsd-advanced.description: The default consumer identifier for metrics. This will take effect when a metric's consumer identifier is omitted. Allowed values are `custom_id`, `consumer_id`, `username`.

statsd-advanced.name: service_identifier_default
statsd-advanced.description: The default service identifier for metrics. This will take effect when a metric's service identifier is omitted. Allowed values are `service_name_or_host`, `service_id`, `service_name`, `service_host`.

statsd-advanced.name: workspace_identifier_default
statsd-advanced.description: The default workspace identifier for metrics. This will take effect when a metric's workspace identifier is omitted. Allowed values are `workspace_id`, `workspace_name`.

statsd.name: host
statsd.description: The IP address or hostname of StatsD server to send data to.

statsd.name: port
statsd.description: The port of StatsD server to send data to.

statsd.name: metrics
statsd.description: List of metrics to be logged. Available values are described under [Metrics](#metrics).

statsd.name: prefix
statsd.description: String to prefix to each metric's name.

statsd.name: hostname_in_prefix
statsd.description: Include the `hostname` in the `prefix` for each metric name.

statsd.name: udp_packet_size
statsd.description:
Combine UDP packet up to the size configured. If zero (0), don't combine the
UDP packet. Must be a number between 0 and 65507 (inclusive).

statsd.name: allow_status_codes
statsd.default: All responses are passed to log metrics
statsd.description: List of status code ranges that are allowed to be logged in metrics.

statsd.name: consumer_identifier_default
statsd.description: The default consumer identifier of metrics. This takes effect when a metric's consumer identifier is omitted. Allowed values are `custom_id`, `consumer_id`, `username`.

statsd.name: service_identifier_default
statsd.description: The default service identifier of metrics. This takes effect when a metric's service identifier is omitted. Allowed values are `service_name_or_host`, `service_id`, `service_name`, `service_host`.

statsd.name: workspace_identifier_default
statsd.description: The default workspace identifier of metrics. This will take effect when a metric's workspace identifier is omitted. Allowed values are `workspace_id`, `workspace_name`.

statsd.name: flush_timeout
statsd.description: Optional time in seconds. If `queue_size` > 1, this is the max idle time before sending a log with less than `queue_size` records.

statsd.name: retry_count
statsd.description: Number of times to retry when sending data to the upstream server.

statsd.name: queue_size
statsd.description: Maximum number of log entries to be sent on each message to the upstream server.

statsd.name: tag_style
